[[Silver Star]] (US) |laterwork= Regional Executive, [[Rolls-Royce plc|Rolls-Royce]] }} [[Air Vice Marshal]] '''Brian Alexander Eaton''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|CB|CBE|DSO1|DFC}} (15 December 1916 – 17 October 1992) was a senior commander in the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF). Born in [[Tasmania]] and raised in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], he joined the RAAF in 1936 and was promoted to [[flight lieutenant]] on the outbreak of World War II. He held training positions before being posted to [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 Squadron]] at the beginning of 1943, flying [[Curtiss P-40 variants|P-40 Kittyhawk]] fighter-bombers in [[North African Campaign|North Africa]]. Despite being shot down three times within ten days soon after arriving, Eaton quickly rose to become the unit's commanding officer, and by year's end had been awarded the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]]. His leadership earned him the [[Distinguished Service Order]] and [[Medal bar|Bar]] in 1944–45, and command of [[List of Royal Air Force wings|No. 239 Wing RAF]] in [[Italian Campaign (World War II)|Italy]], with the temporary rank of [[group captain]]. He was also awarded the US [[Silver Star]] in 1946 in recognition of his war service. In the decade following World War II, Eaton led [[No. 81 Wing RAAF|No. 81 Wing]] in Japan, and [[No. 78 Wing RAAF|No. 78 Wing]] in [[Malta]]. He commanded [[RAAF Base Williamtown]] from 1957 to 1959, after which he was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]]. As Director-General of Operational Requirements in 1965, Eaton argued for increased RAAF co-operation with the [[Australian Army]] in light of growing involvement in the [[Military history of Australia during the Vietnam War|Vietnam War]]. He was promoted to air vice marshal the next year, and became [[Deputy Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Deputy Chief of the Air Staff]]. Posted to [[Singapore]] as [[Air Officer Commanding]] (AOC) [[List of Royal Air Force groups|No. 224 Group RAF]] in 1967, he was appointed a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] for his work as chief of staff at Headquarters [[Far East Air Force (Royal Air Force)|RAF Far East Air Force]] in 1969. He then served as [[Air Member for Personnel (Australia)|Air Member for Personnel]], before being selected as AOC [[RAAF Air Command|Operational Command]] in 1973. Eaton retired from the RAAF in December that year, and became an executive for [[Rolls-Royce plc|Rolls-Royce]] in [[Canberra]]. He died in 1992 at the age of 75. ==Early career== Brian Eaton was born in [[Launceston, Tasmania|Launceston]], Tasmania, on 15 December 1916, to Sydney and Hilda Eaton.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/people_75078.asp|title= Air Vice Marshal Brian Alexander Eaton|publisher= [[Australian War Memorial]]|accessdate=10 April 2010}}{{cite web|url= http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/AWM108/005/005799.pdf|title= Roger Leigh Eaton: Roll of Honour circular|publisher= Australian War Memorial|accessdate= 16 April 2010|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150525013934/https://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/AWM108/005/005799.pdf|archivedate= 25 May 2015|df= dmy-all}} The family later moved to [[Canterbury, Victoria|Canterbury]], Victoria, and Brian was educated at [[Carey Baptist Grammar School|Carey Grammar]]. His early ambition to be a doctor was curtailed when his father died and he had to leave school early.{{cite news|title='The Boss' packs it in|newspaper=[[The Herald (Melbourne)|The Herald]] |page=25|date=12 January 1974}} He enlisted as an air cadet in the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) on 20 January 1936, undergoing flying training at [[RAAF Williams#RAAF Williams Point Cook Base|RAAF Station Point Cook]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?serviceId=R&veteranId=1204686 |title=Eaton, Brian Alexander|publisher= World War 2 Nominal Roll|accessdate= 10 April 2010}} Eaton was commissioned as a [[pilot officer]] upon graduation from flying school in January 1937, and posted to [[No. 1 Squadron RAAF|No. 1 Squadron]]. Within six months he was promoted to [[flying officer]] and joined [[No. 21 Squadron RAAF|No. 21 Squadron]] at [[RAAF Williams#RAAF Williams Laverton Base|RAAF Station Laverton]]. In 1938, he became an [[flight instructor|instructor]] at Point Cook's [[No. 1 Flying Training School RAAF|No. 1 Flying Training School]], where he also took part in the RAAF's early long navigation exercises.Coulthard-Clark, ''Air Marshals of the RAAF'', p. 34Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 207–208 He was promoted to [[flight lieutenant]] on [[Invasion of Poland|1 September 1939]]. ==World War II== ===Early war service=== {{stack|[[File:MED0687Kittyhawk3Sqn1942.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|P-40 Kittyhawk of No. 3 Squadron RAAF during the North African Campaign|alt=Single-engined military monoplane on desert airfield]]}} In April 1940, Eaton was assigned to the newly re-formed [[Central Flying School RAAF|Central Flying School]] at [[Camden, New South Wales|Camden]], New South Wales, as an instructor. Promoted to temporary [[squadron leader]] in September 1940, he was transferred to the Directorate of Training in June 1941. He became a fighter controller at [[No. 5 Fighter Sector RAAF|No. 5 Fighter Sector Headquarters]], [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]], Northern Territory, in March 1942. In October that year, he departed Australia for [[North African Campaign|North Africa]] via India and the United Kingdom, fearful that the fighting would be over before he arrived. He posted in to No. 1 Middle East Training School in January 1943 prior to taking up duties with [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF]], which was then engaged in the [[Tunisia Campaign|Battle of Tunisia]]. Eaton's combat career began inauspiciously, when he was shot down three times in the space of ten days. On the first occasion, his [[Curtiss P-40 variants|P-40 Kittyhawk]] was hit by [[20 mm caliber|20 mm]] cannon shells from an enemy fighter that he never saw. He later recalled, "I was too busy getting the kite down to be frightened. But my God was I surprised." Eaton brought his crippled aircraft in for a forced landing at [[El Hamma]]—in the midst of a tank battle between German and New Zealand forces. After the fighting had died down he made his way over to the New Zealanders, who gave him a lift back to his air base. The second time he was shot down, his plane was struck by [[8.8 cm Flak 18/36/37/41|88 mm]] anti-aircraft fire, necessitating another crash landing, this time behind enemy lines. Sympathetic Arab tribesmen smuggled him past the Germans and back to his airfield. Two days later, his P-40 was hit by fire from an [[Messerschmitt Bf 109|Me 109]] that dived at him from out of the sun. He was able to glide back to base, {{convert|80|mi|km}} away, but on arriving found that it was under attack by German bombers. He decided he had no other option than to land the damaged plane among the exploding bombs, and managed to do so without mishap. His series of narrow escapes engendered a spirit of fatalism, and a habit of keeping his emotions severely in check while on duty: "I just couldn't see myself living when so many were dying. It was something which, at the time, didn't bear much dwelling on."Mordike, ''The RAAF in Europe and North Africa 1939–1945'', pp. 105–107 ===Squadron and wing command=== [[File:MEC0115EatonPortrait1943.jpg|thumb|upright=0.8|left|Squadron Leader Eaton as commanding officer of No. 3 Squadron, Tunisia, May 1943|alt=Head-and-shoulders informal portrait of dark-haired man wearing flying jacket]] Despite his early setbacks in combat, Eaton soon rose to command No. 3 Squadron, taking over from Squadron Leader [[Bobby Gibbes]] on 21 April 1943. He led the unit as it relocated to [[Malta]] the following month, in preparation for the [[Allied invasion of Sicily]].Herington, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/28/chapters/21.pdf ''Air War Against Germany and Italy'', p. 567] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305080713/https://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/28/chapters/21.pdf |date=5 March 2016 }} Illness forced him to hand over command in June–July, but he returned to take charge of the squadron in August as it continued to fly escort and [[interdiction]] missions in Sicily with other units of [[List of Royal Air Force wings|No. 239 Wing RAF]].Herington, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/29/chapters/03.pdf ''Air Power Over Europe'', p. 57] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150427161942/https://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/29/chapters/03.pdf |date=27 April 2015 }}RAAF Historical Section, ''Units of the Royal Australian Air Force. Volume 2: Fighter Units'', p. 7 His brother Roger, a [[flight sergeant]] serving with the RAF, was killed in a [[Vickers Wellington|Wellington]] bomber raid during the campaign. On 3 September, No. 3 Squadron took part in the opening day of the [[Allied invasion of Italy]], supporting the British [[XIII Corps (United Kingdom)|XIII Corps]] as it moved inland after landing at [[Calabria]]. Enemy air resistance remained light and worthwhile ground targets few as the campaign progressed but, on 24 October, Eaton led an attack against German shipping off the [[Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] coast that left a merchant ship and two barges on fire. He repeated the exercise on 7 November, when the squadron scored hits on vessels in two separate raids in the harbour at [[Split (city)|Split]]. On 19 November, when the rest of No. 239 Wing was unable to complete any missions due to adverse weather, Eaton found a hole in the clouds and led eight Kittyhawks in a successful attack on [[Opi (town)|Opi]] in central Italy.Herington, ''Air Power Over Europe'', pp. 68–69 He was promoted to temporary [[Wing Commander (rank)|wing commander]] on 1 December. On 14 December, he was awarded the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] for pressing home a night attack on [[Axis powers|Axis]] armour at [[Termoli]].{{cite web|url= http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/AWM192/00311/003110019.pdf|title= Recommendation: Distinguished Flying Cross|publisher= Australian War Memorial|accessdate= 10 April 2010|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160305132159/https://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/AWM192/00311/003110019.pdf|archivedate= 5 March 2016|df= dmy-all}} The citation was promulgated in the ''[[London Gazette]]'':{{London Gazette|issue= 36459 |supp=y|page=1616|date=14 December 1943}} {{quote|One evening in October, 1943, this officer led his squadron in an attack on a strong enemy force, equipped with tanks, which were attacking our troops near Termoli. In spite of intense antiaircraft fire, Squadron Leader Eaton led his formation in at a low level and pressed home an attack which completely disrupted the enemy's forces. In this spirited action, Squadron Leader Eaton displayed inspiring leadership, great courage and tenacity.}} On 16 February 1944, the day after the contentious destruction of [[Monte Cassino]], Eaton took No. 3 Squadron through a break in the bad weather to attack the ruined monastery, the only one of No. 239 Wing's units to successfully bomb its target that day.Herington, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/29/chapters/04.pdf ''Air Power Over Europe'', p. 104] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306023621/https://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/29/chapters/04.pdf |date=6 March 2016 }}Wilson, ''The Brotherhood of Airmen'', pp. 101–102 He handed over command of No. 3 Squadron later that month, and was transferred to No. 1 Mobile Operations Room Unit as forward air controller for the final [[Battle of Monte Cassino|assault on Monte Cassino]]. The run of luck that Eaton experienced in his first weeks of air combat in Tunisia continued on the ground in Italy. He survived three months of constant artillery fire, including an occasion when a shell exploded directly above his observation post, striking down a British officer standing next to him. He also came under machine-gun fire when he took a wrong turn one day and drove into the German lines, but again escaped unhurt. He was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] on 7 April, in recognition of his leadership of No. 3 Squadron in North Africa, Malta, Sicily and Italy.{{cite web |url=http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/AWM192/00311/003110017.pdf |title=Recommendation: Distinguished Service Order |publisher=Australian War Memorial |accessdate=10 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305073025/https://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/AWM192/00311/003110017.pdf |archivedate=5 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}{{London Gazette|issue= 36459 |supp=y|page=1616|date=7 April 1944}} [[File:MED1725Eaton239Wing1945.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.4|Acting Group Captain Eaton (centre, cutting cake) and personnel of No. 239 Wing, at the formation's third anniversary celebration in [[Fano]], Italy, 28 April 1945|alt=Large group of cheering men in military uniforms surround a man cutting a three-decker birthday cake on a long table]] Raised to acting [[group captain]], Eaton was given command of No. 239 Wing on 3 August 1944, taking responsibility for No. 3 Squadron and [[No. 450 Squadron RAAF]], [[No. 112 Squadron RAF|No. 112 Squadron]] and [[List of Royal Air Force aircraft squadrons|No. 260 Squadron RAF]], No. 5 Squadron of the [[South African Air Force]], and No. 250 Squadron of the [[Royal Rhodesian Air Force]]. Credited with leading "many outstanding raids", he was known to his staff as "The Boss", and often flew twice a day with a different squadron on each mission; when his superiors found out how many sorties he was personally undertaking and ordered him to cut back, he simply ceased recording his flying hours.Herington, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/29/chapters/14.pdf ''Air Power Over Europe'', p. 351] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150427144548/https://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/29/chapters/14.pdf |date=27 April 2015 }} The wing's two RAF squadrons had already re-equipped with [[P-51 Mustang]]s when Eaton took over; No. 5 converted in September and No. 3 in November. As well as supporting the [[Eighth Army (United Kingdom)|Eighth Army]] in Italy, the Mustang units carried out missions in Yugoslavia in concert with the [[Balkan Air Force]], prior to Axis forces surrendering on 2 May.Herington, ''Air Power Over Europe'', pp. 353–356Scutts, ''Mustang Aces of the Ninth & Fifteenth Air Forces & the RAF'', pp. 48–51 Eaton was unofficially credited with shooting down as many as seven enemy aircraft during the Mediterranean campaigns, but was never listed among Australian [[flying ace]]s. Many of the missions that he undertook with No. 3 Squadron and in command of No. 239 Wing were ground attack or anti-shipping sorties, rather than air-to-air combat. He was also known as a leader who, when opportunities did arise to engage other aircraft, would attempt to manoeuvre his rookie pilots into position to make a "kill", rather than take the shot himself. On 12 June, he was awarded a [[Medal bar|Bar]] to his Distinguished Service Order for "Outstanding skill and leadership against heavy odds".{{cite web |url=http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/AWM192/00311/003110018.pdf |title=Recommendation: Bar to Distinguished Service Order |publisher=Australian War Memorial |accessdate=10 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150427144600/https://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/AWM192/00311/003110018.pdf |archivedate=27 April 2015 |df=dmy-all }}{{London Gazette|issue= 37125 |supp=y|page=3083|date=12 June 1945}} His war service also earned him the US [[Silver Star]], permission to wear it being [[London Gazette|gazetted]] on 14 June 1946.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/research/people/honours_and_awards/person.asp?p=391320|title=Recommendation: US Silver Star|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=10 April 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606092943/http://www.awm.gov.au/research/people/honours_and_awards/person.asp?p=391320|archivedate=6 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}{{London Gazette|issue= 37610 |supp=y|page=3007|date=14 June 1946}} ==Post-war career== ===Rise to senior command=== [[File:JK0145EatonKorea1951.jpg|left|thumb|upright=1.2|Wing Commander Eaton in a No. 77 Squadron [[Gloster Meteor|Meteor]] during a visit to [[Korean War|Korea]], October 1951|alt=Man in flying cap and goggles sitting in aircraft cockpit]] Eaton was posted to Britain following the end of World War II, and attended [[RAF Staff College, Andover|RAF Staff College]] the next year. In September 1947, he was appointed Officer Commanding [[No. 81 Wing RAAF|No. 81 (Fighter) Wing]] in Japan, as part of the [[British Commonwealth Occupation Force]] (BCOF). The Australian contingent initially comprised three combat units, [[No. 76 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 76]], [[No. 77 Squadron RAAF|77]] and [[No. 82 Squadron RAAF|82 Squadrons]], as well as No. 381 (Base) Squadron, No. 481 (Maintenance) Squadron, No. 111 Mobile Fighter Control Unit, and [[No. 5 Airfield Construction Squadron RAAF|No. 5 Airfield Construction Squadron]]. By mid-1949, it had been reduced to No. 77 Squadron alone, and Headquarters BCOF had been disbanded; Eaton served as "RAAF Component" commander for the remainder of his tenure in Japan.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 208–211, 214, 217, 222 As well as surveillance patrols, training and inter-service exercises, the Australian airmen took part in ceremonial flypasts. On one such occasion, over Tokyo, Eaton led his formation of thirty Mustangs into cloud with a faulty [[artificial horizon]] in his plane, with the result that he and his comrades, who were following his lead, became badly disorientated and were fortunate to avoid collision; RAAF historian Alan Stephens considered this a not-atypical example of the casual attitude to flying safety exhibited at the time by the veteran pilots of World War II.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 216–219 Returning to Australia in November 1949, Eaton became Deputy Director of Training at the Department of Air, [[Canberra]], where he remained until 1951. Later that year, he was appointed Officer Commanding [[No. 78 Wing RAAF|No. 78 (Fighter) Wing]] at [[RAAF Base Williamtown]], New South Wales.Wilson, ''The Brotherhood of Airmen'', p. 144 He had reverted to a substantive rank of wing commander since leaving Japan, as the RAAF shrank dramatically with demobilisation and many senior officers lost the temporary or acting ranks they had gained in wartime.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 24–25 On 15 September, he landed a [[De Havilland Vampire|Vampire]] jet fighter at Point Cook with one flat tyre and one wheel retracted, after its undercarriage had become jammed. The plane skidded off the runway but Eaton was able to walk away, reportedly remarking "Well, I didn't wreck it".{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18496297?|title=Jet Lands on one flat tyre|newspaper=[[Sunday Herald (Australia)|Sunday Herald]] |date=16 September 1951 |accessdate=18 April 2010|page=1}} He married Josephine Rumbles at [[Toorak, Victoria|Toorak]] Presbyterian Church in Melbourne on 10 May 1952; the couple later had a son and two daughters.Draper, ''Who's Who in Australia 1983'', p. 275{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zCcRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GcQDAAAAIBAJ&dq=eaton%20raaf&pg=7224%2C1315745|title=Jet Fighter CO weds|newspaper=[[The Age]] |date=12 May 1952 |accessdate=18 April 2010|page=3}} Following Britain's request to the Australian government for a Commonwealth garrison in the Mediterranean, in July 1952 Eaton led No. 78 Wing on deployment to [[RAF Hal Far]] near [[Valletta]], Malta, where its combat squadrons, [[No. 75 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 75]] and 76, were equipped with leased Vampire FB9s. As the overseas posting was for a minimum of two years, his new bride and the families of other staff were permitted to make the journey as well.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 202–203{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18507522|title=They're off to the Middle East: brides going, too—on honeymoon|newspaper= The Sunday Herald |date=29 June 1952 |accessdate=18 April 2010|page=5}} The Australian airmen participated in many [[NATO]] exercises while stationed at Malta, and one year took first and second place in the Middle Eastern Gunnery Contest for the [[Ernest Mason|"Imshi" Mason Cup]].Newton, ''Clash of Eagles'', p. 111 Promoted to the substantive rank of group captain on 1 January 1953, Eaton was granted command of [[Ta' Qali|RAF Ta'Kali]] when the wing transferred there from Hal Far in June.{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2872179?|title=Promotions in RAAF|newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |date=1 January 1953 |accessdate=18 April 2010|page=2}}Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 206 [[File:MALTA0910EatonMountbatten1954.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.4|Group Captain Eaton as Officer Commanding No. 78 Wing in Malta, with [[Edwina Mountbatten, Countess Mountbatten of Burma|Countess Edwina Mountbatten]], following the [[Anzac Day]] service on 25 April 1954|alt=Informal outdoor portrait of man and woman both wearing dark military uniforms with medals and peaked caps]] Completing his tour with No. 78 Wing in mid-1954, Eaton joined Air Vice Marshal [[Alister Murdoch]] on an international mission to examine potential new fighter, bomber, transport and training aircraft for the RAAF.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 38–39Stephens, ''Power Plus Attitude'', pp. 142, 160 The team's report advocated the [[Lockheed F-104 Starfighter|F-104 Starfighter]] as a replacement for the [[CAC Sabre]],Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 354 as well as [[Nuclear warfare|nuclear-capable]] British [[V bomber|V-bomber]] strike aircraft to augment Australia's [[English Electric Canberra|Canberra]] bombers, and [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules|C-130 Hercules]] transports to replace the [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain|C-47 Dakota]]. While the proposals for V-bombers and the F-104 were not taken up, the Australian Government acquired the C-130 in 1958. Described as second only to the [[General Dynamics F-111C]] as the "most significant" purchase by the RAAF, the Hercules gave the Air Force its first [[Airlift#Strategic airlift|strategic airlift]] capability, which in years to come would provide a "lifeline" to Australian forces deployed to [[Malayan Emergency|Malaya]], [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]], and other parts of the South-West Pacific.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 416–18 The mission also recommended the locally built Vampire T35 as a jet trainer for No. 1 Applied Flying Training School; sixty-nine were later delivered by the [[de Havilland]] factory in [[Bankstown, New South Wales|Bankstown]], New South Wales.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 160–161 Eaton served as RAAF Director of Operations during 1955–56, and as Officer Commanding RAAF Base Williamtown and Commandant of the co-located School of Land-Air Warfare from March 1957 until February 1959.RAAF Historical Section, ''Units of the Royal Australian Air Force: Bases'', p. 171 He was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the 1959 [[Queen's Birthday Honours]].{{London Gazette|issue=41728 |supp=y|page=3736|date=13 June 1959}} Following his tour at Williamtown, Eaton spent two years as Director of Joint Services Plans before attending the [[Royal College of Defence Studies|Imperial Defence College, London]] in 1961. Raised to [[air commodore]], he was appointed Director-General Operational Requirements in 1962. Concurrently he became an Honorary [[Aide-de-Camp]] to [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]], in which capacity he served until 1965. As the Army reorganised to deal with [[Military history of Australia during the Vietnam War|Australia's increasing commitments to the Vietnam War]] in the mid-1960s, it sought to procure a dozen twin-engined aircraft of a size hitherto only operated by the RAAF, and also proposed a joint review of [[close air support]]. RAAF senior command chose to deal with the Army's proposals by ignoring them. As Director-General of Operational Requirements, Eaton argued that if the RAAF did not more fully satisfy the ground support requirements of the Army, then the Army itself would seek to take control of this sphere of operations, undermining the RAAF's position as the main provider of Australia's air power. Pointing out to the [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]], Air Marshal Murdoch, that it was "clearly the Army's intention to have complete command and control" of air-to-ground assets, he warned of a parallel situation in America, where the [[United States Army|US Army]] was looking to take over all battlefield air support in response to the [[United States Air Force|USAF]] failing to keep up to date in the provision of basic attack aircraft. The RAAF's refusal to adequately deal with its ground support responsibilities led to long-running inter-service enmity, and contributed to the Australian government's decision twenty years later to transfer control of battlefield helicopters to the Army.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 317–322Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 298 At this time, Eaton also led the acquisition team that selected the [[Aermacchi MB-326|Macchi MB-326]] as the RAAF's new jet trainer, as it met all requirements, could be licence-built in Australia, and was relatively inexpensive. The first of ninety-seven was delivered by the [[Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation]] in 1967.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 161–163 ===Senior command and retirement=== [[File:RAAF Commonwealth CA-30 (MB-326H) landing at RAAF Air Base Edinburgh.jpg|left|thumb|upright=1.2|Macchi MB-326, selected as the RAAF's jet trainer in the mid-1960s by an acquisition team led by Air Commodore Eaton|alt=Side view of two-seat, single-engined military jet in flight, wheels down]] Promoted to [[air vice marshal]], Eaton became [[Deputy Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Deputy Chief of the Air Staff]] in 1966. In December that year, with Australian [[de Havilland Canada DHC-4 Caribou|Caribou]] transports and [[Bell UH-1 Iroquois|Iroquois]] helicopters already serving in Vietnam, Eaton advocated building up the RAAF's "sharp end" there, increasing air support for ground troops. He preferred deploying Sabre or [[Dassault Mirage III|Mirage]] fighters rather than the mooted Canberra bombers, which he saw as more suitable for a strategic role. Above all, he accepted the "[[domino theory]]" and believed that if Australia did not aid South Vietnam, "we'd lose the lot". In the event, Canberras were despatched rather than fighters.Stephens, ''Power Plus Attitude'', pp. 124, 132Coulthard-Clark, ''The RAAF in Vietnam'', pp. 90–91 In 1967, Eaton became the last AOC of [[List of Royal Air Force groups|No. 224 Group RAF]] under the British Far East Air Force (FEAF) in [[Singapore]], as permanent squadrons were dropped from its strength. This reorganisation led to him taking over as chief of staff at Headquarters FEAF the following year.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 255 In this capacity, he was appointed a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] (CB) in the 1969 Queen's Birthday Honours.{{London Gazette|issue= 44864 |supp=y|page=5995|date=14 June 1969}} Returning to Australia, Eaton became Air Member for Personnel (AMP) in October 1969. As AMP, he sat on the [[Air Board (Australia)|Air Board]], the RAAF's controlling body, consisting of its most senior officers and chaired by the Chief of the Air Staff.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 500Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 112 In January 1973, he was appointed AOC Operational Command (now [[RAAF Air Command|Air Command]]). He served in this position until retirement, his tenure witnessing the introduction of the F-111C [[Variable-sweep wing|swing-wing]] bomber to service in Australia, when the first machines touched down at [[RAAF Base Amberley]], Queensland, in July. Leaving the military on 15 December 1973,Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 290 Eaton became Regional Executive for [[Rolls Royce plc|Rolls Royce Australia]] in Canberra. He remained with the company for the next decade, continuing to live in Canberra until his death on 17 October 1992, at the age of 75. In 1996, his widow Josephine donated funding for the Air Vice-Marshal B.A. Eaton 'Airman of the Year' Award to the RAAF, to annually recognise "significant contribution to both the Service and the community" by [[Ranks of the RAAF#Airmen|airmen and airwoman]] ranked [[corporal]] or below.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/Awards/ |title=Air Vice-Marshal B.A. Eaton Award (Airman of the year)|publisher= [[Royal Australian Air Force]]|accessdate= 16 April 2010}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== * {{cite book|last=Coulthard-Clark | first=Chris |year=1995| title=Air Marshals of the RAAF 1935–1995 | location=Canberra| publisher=[[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence]] (Air Force Office)|isbn=}} * {{cite book|last=Coulthard-Clark| first=Chris|year=1991| title=The Third Brother| location=North Sydney| publisher=[[Allen & Unwin]]|isbn=0-04-442307-1}} * {{cite book|last=Coulthard-Clark | first=Chris| year=1995| title=The RAAF in Vietnam: Australian Air Involvement in the Vietnam War 1962–1975| location=St Leonards, New South Wales| publisher=Allen & Unwin in association with the [[Australian War Memorial]]|isbn=1-86373-305-1}} * {{cite book|last=Draper| first=W.J. [[Prakash Raj]] | music = [[S. Thaman]] | cinematography = [[Shyam K. Naidu]] | editing = S. R. Shekhar | studio = [[R. R. Movie Makers]] | distributor = R. R. Movie Makers | released = {{Film date|df=yes|2012|01|13}} | runtime = 131 minutes | country = India | language = [[Telugu language|Telugu]] | budget = {{INRconvert|400|m|year=2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessworld.in/news/null/the-south-side-story/696844/page-1.html|title=The South Side Story|last=John|first=Nevin|publisher=[[Businessworld]]|date=3 January 2013|accessdate=19 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219173038/http://www.businessworld.in/news/null/the-south-side-story/696844/page-1.html|archivedate=19 February 2015}} | gross = {{INRconvert|550|m|year=2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/tamil/article1393872.ece|title=Year of small films at southern box-office|author=[[Indo-Asian News Service|IANS]]|publisher=''[[The New Indian Express]]''|date=16 August 2011|accessdate=19 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219173150/http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/tamil/article1393872.ece|archivedate=19 February 2015}} }} '''''Businessman''''', also known as '''''The Businessman''''', is a 2012 Indian [[Telugu language|Telugu-language]] [[action film]][http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/businessman-guns-dont-need-agreements-2012 BUSINESSMAN: GUNS DON'T NEED AGREEMENTS | British Board of Film Classification] written and directed by [[Puri Jagannadh]]. Based on a concept by [[Ram Gopal Varma]] and produced by [[R. R. Venkat]] under the banner [[R. R. Movie Makers]], the film features [[Mahesh Babu]] and [[Kajal Aggarwal]] in the lead roles, with [[Nassar]], [[Prakash Raj]], [[Sayaji Shinde]], [[Raza Murad]] and [[Brahmaji]] in supporting roles. Mahesh plays Vijay Surya, who later becomes Surya Bhai a ruthless man who comes to [[Mumbai]] from [[South India]] aspiring to become a mafia don. Surya arrives just as the Mumbai police declare the end of the "[[Mafia Raj]]" and begins his journey by helping a local politician and trapping the city commissioner's daughter, only to fall in love with her. He eventually emerges as the biggest mafia leader of Mumbai and kills a national politician Jai Dev in retribution for cheating and murdering his parents. [[S. Thaman]] composed the film's music and [[Shyam K. Naidu]] was the film's cinematographer. The film was made with a budget of {{INR}}400 million and was launched formally on 15 August 2011 at [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]]. [[Principal photography]] began on 2 September 2011 and was shot in Hyderabad, [[Mumbai]] and [[Goa]]. A few song sequences were shot in [[Bangkok]]. Filming ended on 10 December 2011 in 74 working days, one of the shortest periods in which a Telugu film has been shot. Released during [[Sankranthi]]{{efn|Sankranthi is an Indian traditional [[harvest festival]] celebrated on 14 January of [[gregorian calendar]]. It is a solar event making one of the few Indian festivals which fall on the same date in the calendar with some exceptions when the festival is celebrated on 13 or 15 January}} on 13 January 2012, the film received mixed feedback from critics, but was commercially successful. It grossed more than {{INR}}550 million and collected a distributor share of {{INR}}448 million, eventually becoming one of the highest grossing Telugu films of 2012. == Plot == [[File:Mumbai 03-2016 52 Dharavi near Mahim Junction.jpg|thumb|The [[Dharavi]] slum in [[Mumbai]], the film's setting.]] [[Mumbai]] Police commissioner Ajay Bhardwaj announces the end of the "[[Mafia Raj]]" in the city, to try to bring peace to the city's streets. However, a ruthless south Indian named Vijay Surya comes to the city, aspiring to be the most powerful Mafia Don there. Staying in [[Dharavi]] with his friend, he is introduced to a local politician Laalu, who is in trouble and offers him help. He recruits a portion of the gangsters and criminals living in Mumbai led by Naseer to work under him. Surya's henchman Shakeel manages to kill a witness of Laalu's crimes in the jail where he is kept in, winning Laalu's friendship. After this, Surya promises to clear the debts of Dharavi locals so that their houses will not be repossessed. His men rob the original copies of the loan documents in the local branch of [[Bank of Maharashtra]] and destroy the bank records. Surya slowly becomes both popular and feared as an extortionist, while Dharavi locals praise him as their saviour. Surya is aware of Bhardwaj's intentions. To safeguard himself, he traps Bhardwaj's daughter Chitra, a keen painter, by posing as a NRI businessman interested in arts. They both fall in love. However, by the time Surya realises that he truly loves her, Bhardwaj has exposed Surya's real nature to Chitra which makes her hate him. Surya is immediately arrested. Surya is released after manipulating Bhardwaj by having his associates kidnap Chitra. He promises to leave crime behind him and asks Bhardwaj for permission to marry Chitra. When they refuse his proposal, he insists to Bhardwaj that he will set up a business which is untouchable by the police, and will eventually marry Chitra. Surya sets up a company named "Surya Exports & Imports" as a front for the organised crime that they indulge in. He plans to grow his organised crime network all over India and begins to set up branch offices for "Surya Exports & Imports" in all major cities, towns and villages all over India. He recruits local gangsters for staff and begins to forcibly collect a two percent tax on every contract made in that area. Surya amasses a huge fortune, making him a billionaire, and during the inauguration of his "Business Bank", he reveals his thirst for power to Bhardwaj. He claims that the crime rate dropped significantly after he started to recruit all the gangsters. He also states that he wants to rid India of crime and help the needy. Next, Surya helps Laalu to become the Mayor of Mumbai by defeating Arun Ghokle, endorsed by Ghanapuleti Jai Dev, a powerful national politician who wants to become the new prime minister of India in the upcoming elections. Ghokle then reveals Jai Dev's illegal scams to Bhardwaj, after which he is killed by Jai Dev. After the meeting, Surya comes to know that Jai Dev is planning to kill Bhardwaj and Chitra. He reaches Chitra's house and saves her but fails to save Bhardwaj. Chitra is devastated and Surya reveals to her that he was an American-born Indian who lost his philanthropist NRI father and mother at an early age; they were cheated and killed by Jai Dev. This incident and the peoples' attitudes towards orphans while growing up made him hate that society. Surya shifts his attention towards the upcoming [[Elections in India|Indian parliament elections]] and meets Guru Govind Patel, the head of the opposition party through Laalu. He makes a deal with him, offering {{INR}}350 billion for election campaigning and also promises him that he would make him the prime minister of India. Surya spends millions on every constituency in India, making Jai Dev unable to contest in the elections by revealing his illegal affairs. Jai Dev kidnaps Chitra to seek revenge on Surya, who fights with Jai Dev's henchmen. He is injured, but eventually kills Jai Dev, saving Chitra and proposing to her for the last time. It is revealed at the end that Surya successfully installed Guru Govind Patel as the Prime Minister of India. Character shown at 92:00 {{colend}} == Production == === Development === [[Ram Gopal Varma]] signed [[Suriya]] for a multilingual [[crime film]] titled ''The Businessman'' in May 2010, to be directed by [[Puri Jagannadh]] simultaneously in [[Telugu language|Telugu]], [[Tamil language|Tamil]] and [[Hindi language|Hindi]]. The film's protagonist was supposed to be a south Indian coming to [[Mumbai]] and setting up a crime business using tact and intelligence to emerge as one of the biggest gangsters.{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/suriya-signs-another-rgv-film-news-tamil-kkfq7Mdagbesi.html|title=Suriya signs another RGV film?|publisher=[[Sify]]|date=17 May 2010|accessdate=18 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218171043/http://www.sify.com/movies/suriya-signs-another-rgv-film-news-tamil-kkfq7Mdagbesi.html|archivedate=18 February 2015}} The film's production was expected to begin in October 2010 once Suriya completed his part in ''[[7aum Arivu]]'' (2011) and was scheduled for release in the summer of 2011. Jagannadh stated in an interview that [[principal photography]] would begin in September 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmibeat.com/telugu/news/2010/puri-speaks-businessman-240510.html|title=Puri Jagannath speaks on The Businessman|author=Ramchander|publisher=[[Oneindia.com|Oneindia Entertainment]]|date=24 May 2010|accessdate=18 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218171050/http://www.filmibeat.com/telugu/news/2010/puri-speaks-businessman-240510.html|archivedate=18 February 2015}} It was speculated that the film was to be based on the real-life story of a gangster who had moved from the [[Cuddalore district]] of [[Tamil Nadu]] to Mumbai in the late 1960s.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmibeat.com/tamil/news/2010/surya-businessman-gangster-220610.html|title=Surya's Businessman — a biopic on a gangster?|author=Ramchander|publisher=Oneindia Entertainment|date=22 June 2010|accessdate=18 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218171040/http://www.filmibeat.com/tamil/news/2010/surya-businessman-gangster-220610.html|archivedate=18 February 2015}} The film was revived later by [[R. R. Venkat]] later in January 2011 with a tagline "Guns do not need agreements". He signed [[Mahesh Babu]] as the protagonist who worked with Jagannadh in the past for ''[[Pokiri]]'' (2006).{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/mahesh-babu-s-the-businessman-news-telugu-lbvthLgejhbsi.html|title=Mahesh Babu`s `The Businessman`|publisher=Sify|date=22 January 2011|accessdate=18 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218171240/http://www.sify.com/movies/mahesh-babu-s-the-businessman-news-telugu-lbvthLgejhbsi.html|archivedate=18 February 2015}} Venkat added that the film would be produced under the banner [[R. R. Movie Makers]].{{cite web|url=http://www.filmibeat.com/telugu/news/2011/puri-jagannath-mahesh-babu-businessman-290111-aid0062.html|title=Puri Jagannath teaming up with Mahesh Babu for The Businessman|author=Ramchander|publisher=Oneindia Entertainment|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=18 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218171429/http://www.filmibeat.com/telugu/news/2011/puri-jagannath-mahesh-babu-businessman-290111-aid0062.html|archivedate=18 February 2015}} Jagannadh completed the final draft of the film's script on 25 July 2011 during his stay at [[Bangkok]], adding that he was inspired by Ram Gopal Varma. He stated that the pending pre-production work would begin in [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]] after a week.{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/script-for-mahesh-babu-s-next-news-news-lhzp7hhchigsi.html|title=Script for Mahesh Babu`s next|publisher=Sify|date=25 July 2011|accessdate=18 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218171532/http://www.sify.com/movies/script-for-mahesh-babu-s-next-news-news-lhzp7hhchigsi.html|archivedate=18 February 2015}} The film had its formal launch on 15 August 2011 with a small [[Puja (Hinduism)|pooja]] ceremony conducted at Hyderabad.{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/pooja-for-the-business-man-held-news-news-liqktCebfhesi.html|title=Pooja for The Business Man held|publisher=Sify|date=16 August 2011|accessdate=18 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218171643/http://www.sify.com/movies/pooja-for-the-business-man-held-news-news-liqktCebfhesi.html|archivedate=18 February 2015}} [[Shyam K. Naidu]] and [[S. Thaman]] were confirmed as the film's cinematographer and music director respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/mahesh-s-the-businessman-launched-news-news-liqpPqdfgggsi.html|title=Mahesh`s The Businessman launched|publisher=Sify|date=16 August 2011|accessdate=18 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218171544/http://www.sify.com/movies/mahesh-s-the-businessman-launched-news-news-liqpPqdfgggsi.html|archivedate=18 February 2015}} === Casting === {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | footer = [[Shruti Haasan]] (''top'') was initially considered for the female lead role, but [[Kajal Aggarwal]] (''bottom'') ended up being engaged for the role. | width = | image1 = Shruti Haasan TeachAIDS Interview1.png | width1 = 200 | alt1 = | caption1 = | image2 = Kajal Aggarwal 3.jpg | width2 = 200 | alt2 = | caption2 = }} Mahesh received the film's script while [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbing]] for ''[[Dookudu]]'' (2011), but due to that commitment took ten days to finish reading the script. did not cast [[Brahmanandam]] and [[Ali (actor)|Ali]] because of Mahesh's specific characterisation; he added that Mahesh's voice had changed when compared to his performance in ''Pokiri''.{{cite was paid {{INR}}10 million for this film.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmibeat.com/telugu/news/2012/kajal-aggarwal-businessman-mahesh-babu-120112.html|title=Kajal Aggarwal's expensive deal with confirmed reports stating Mahesh and Kajal sharing a kiss in the film, adding that he retained them after Mahesh's wife [[Namrata Shirodkar]] approved it. It was reportedly the first onscreen kiss for both of them.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/tamil/movies/news/Mahesh-Babu-locks-lips-with-Kajal/articleshow/11388836.cms|title=Mahesh Babu locks lips with |archivedate=19 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} [[Prakash Raj]], [[Nassar]], [[Sayaji Shinde]], [[Dharmavarapu Subramanyam]], [[Brahmaji]] and [[Bandla Ganesh]] among others were cast for key supporting roles.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaglitz.com/the-businessman-will-be-biggest-range-film-mahesh-telugu-news-71190|title=The Businessman will be 'biggest range' film: Bhardwaj]] was therefore selected to perform the item number instead.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaglitz.com/and-businessman-too-has-an-item-song-telugu-news-72356|title=And Businessman too has an She also tried to understand the meaning of the lyrics while dancing. Bhardwaj was afraid of dancing, suspecting a possible sprain, and found the costumes uneasy, but had to continue upon the choreographer's insistence.{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-south-shwetha-bhardwaj-i-am-a-die-hard-nagarjuna-fan/20120215.htm|title='I am a die-hard Nagarjuna fan'|last=Rajamani|first=Radhika|publisher=Rediff.com|date=15 February 2012|accessdate=19 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219025716/http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-south-shwetha-bhardwaj-i-am-a-die-hard-nagarjuna-fan/20120215.htm|archivedate=19 February 2015}} Canadian-born Indian actress Ayesha Shiva was signed to play Kajal's friend in the film.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Tollywood-calling-Ayesha-Shiva/articleshow/15545933.cms|title=Tollywood calling : Ayesha Shiva|last=Pasupulate|first=Karthik|publisher=''[[The Times of India]]''|date=18 August 2012|accessdate=19 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219025714/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Tollywood-calling-Ayesha-Shiva/articleshow/15545933.cms|archivedate=19 February 2015}} === Filming === [[File:Hyderabad Airport.jpg|thumb|[[Rajiv Gandhi International Airport]], where [[principal photography]] began.]] The film was planned to be shot entirely in and around Mumbai and Jagannadh searched for distinct localities there which suit the script's backdrops.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaglitz.com/channels/telugu/article/69801.html|title=The Businessman formally launched|publisher=IndiaGlitz|date=15 August 2011|accessdate=19 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219031356/http://www.indiaglitz.com/channels/telugu/article/69801.html|archivedate=19 February 2015}} Jagannadh told Venkat that he needed 75 working days to complete the film's shoot. He planned to start with Mahesh in the first week of September 2011 and established this schedule before finishing in the first week of January 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/puri-wants-75-days-for-the-businessman-news-news-lixkbLhcbeesi.html|title=Puri wants 75 days for The Businessman|publisher=Sify|date=23 August 2011|accessdate=19 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219031456/http://www.sify.com/movies/puri-wants-75-days-for-the-businessman-news-news-lixkbLhcbeesi.html|archivedate=19 February 2015}} Filming began on 2 September 2011 at [[Rajiv Gandhi International Airport]] in Hyderabad.{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/the-businessman-rolls-on-news-news-ljckQkgcggjsi.html|title=The Businessman rolls on|publisher=Sify|date=2 September 2011|accessdate=19 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219031353/http://www.sify.com/movies/the-businessman-rolls-on-news-news-ljckQkgcggjsi.html|archivedate=19 February 2015}} The second schedule began at Mumbai from 20 September 2011 and Mahesh confirmed in an interview that it would last until 5 December 2011. An action sequence choreographed by Vijayan was shot in mid October 2011 and it was announced that the film's climax would be shot in and around Goa from 27 October 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaglitz.com/the-businessman-to-shoot-climax-from-oct-27-telugu-news-71979|title=The Businessman to shoot climax from Oct. 27|publisher=IndiaGlitz|date=13 October 2011|accessdate=19 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219031536/http://www.indiaglitz.com/the-businessman-to-shoot-climax-from-oct-27-telugu-news-71979|archivedate=19 February 2015}} The song "We Want Bad Boys" was shot in late October 2011. At the same time, Jagannadh planned to shoot a couple of songs with Mahesh and Kajal in Spain during November 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaglitz.com/the-businessman-song-in-spain-telugu-news-73066|title=The Businessman song in Spain|publisher=IndiaGlitz|date=24 October 2011|accessdate=19 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219031644/http://www.indiaglitz.com/the-businessman-song-in-spain-telugu-news-73066|archivedate=19 February 2015}} The filming of the climax sequences featuring Mahesh, Prakash Raj and others was finished by 2 November 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaglitz.com/mahesh-shooting-for-climax-telugu-news-73441|title=Mahesh shooting for climax|publisher=IndiaGlitz|date=2 November 2011|accessdate=19 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219031634/http://www.indiaglitz.com/mahesh-shooting-for-climax-telugu-news-73441|archivedate=19 February 2015}} After filming two songs in the districts of Krabi and Pattaya in Bangkok, the film's unit returned to Hyderabad on 2 December 2011 for completing patch work. The film's shooting was wrapped up on 10 December 2011 in 74 working days as expected.{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/businessman-completed-in-just-74-days-news-news-lmmkqGehifhsi.html|title=Businessman completed in just 74 days|publisher=Sify|date=12 December 2011|accessdate=19 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219031751/http://www.sify.com/movies/businessman-completed-in-just-74-days-news-news-lmmkqGehifhsi.html|archivedate=19 February 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaglitz.com/businessman-to-wrap-up-by-dec-10-telugu-news-74867|title=Businessman to wrap up by Dec. 10|publisher=IndiaGlitz|date=2 December 2011|accessdate=19 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219031633/http://www.indiaglitz.com/businessman-to-wrap-up-by-dec-10-telugu-news-74867|archivedate=19 February 2015}} Jagannadh revealed in an interview that the film's length by the end of shoot was 84,000 feet as planned. He added that Mahesh and Kajal participated in the film's shoot for 65 and 30 days respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaglitz.com/businessman-on-dot-telugu-news-75355|title=Businessman on dot|publisher=IndiaGlitz|date=12 December 2011|accessdate=19 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219031749/http://www.indiaglitz.com/businessman-on-dot-telugu-news-75355|archivedate=19 February 2015}} === Post production === The film's [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbing]] activities began on 15 December 2011 at Shabdalaya Studios in Hyderabad. The DTS mixing works were in progress in early January 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmibeat.com/telugu/news/2012/mahesh-babu-the-businessman-release-050112.html|title=Mahesh Babu starrer The Businessman release postponed|publisher=Oneindia Entertainment|date=5 January 2012|accessdate=21 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221160045/http://www.filmibeat.com/telugu/news/2012/mahesh-babu-the-businessman-release-050112.html|archivedate=21 February 2015}} The [[Central Board of Film Certification]] passed the film with an 'A' certificate; board members found few of the film's dialogues offensive and potentially upsetting to the people of Mumbai.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/A-certificate-for-Businessman/articleshow/11424782.cms|title=‘A’ certificate for Businessman|last=Pasupulate|first=Karthik|publisher=''The Times of India''|date=10 January 2012|accessdate=21 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221160058/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/A-certificate-for-Businessman/articleshow/11424782.cms|archivedate=21 February 2015}} == Music == {{Main|Businessman (soundtrack)}} The soundtrack consists of six songs composed by [[S. Thaman]] and written by [[Bhaskarabhatla Ravi Kumar]].{{cite web|url=http://play.raaga.com/telugu/album/businessman-a0002849|title=Telugu tracklist|publisher=[[Raaga.com]]|date=22 December 2011|accessdate=23 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223151718/http://play.raaga.com/telugu/album/businessman-a0002849|archivedate=23 February 2015}} [[Aditya Music]] acquired the audio rights.{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/aditya-music-s-gift-to-mahesh-fans-news-news-lm0lJuhaifjsi.html|title=Aditya Music`s gift to Mahesh fans|publisher=Sify|date=26 December 2011|accessdate=21 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221161118/http://www.sify.com/movies/aditya-music-s-gift-to-mahesh-fans-news-news-lm0lJuhaifjsi.html|archivedate=21 February 2015}} The original along with both the dubbed versions of the soundtrack were released on 22 December 2011 at [[Shilpakala Vedika]] in [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]].{{cite web|url=http://www.filmibeat.com/telugu/news/2011/the-businessman-audio-storm-tomorrow-211211.html|title=The Businessman audio to storm the stands tomorrow|author=Ramchander|publisher=Oneindia Entertainment|date=21 December 2011|accessdate=23 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223152354/http://www.filmibeat.com/telugu/news/2011/the-businessman-audio-storm-tomorrow-211211.html|archivedate=23 February 2015}} [[Na. web|url=http://www.indiaglitz.com/business-man-awarded-a-telugu-news-76225|title=Business Man awarded 'A'|publisher=IndiaGlitz|date=3 January 2012|accessdate=21 February Thaman was criticised for copying the tunes of the [[Italian resistance movement|Italian partisan]] song "[[Bella ciao]]" for the song "Pilla Chao"and "[[He Lives in You]]", a song written and performed by [[Lebo M]] and his South African Choir for the album ''[[Rhythm of the Pride Lands]]'' (1995), for the song "Chandamama".{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/how-bella-ciao-turned-into-pilla-chao/article2750486.ece|title=How ‘Bella Ciao' turned into ‘Pilla Chao'|publisher=''[[The Hindu]]''|date=27 December 2011|accessdate=23 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223150632/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/how-bella-ciao-turned-into-pilla-chao/article2750486.ece|archivedate=23 February 2015}} "Pilla Chao" was one of the more successful songs on the soundtrack and many music lovers left angry comments about the plagiarism on the song's [[YouTube]] video.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/tamil/movies/news/Pilla-Chao-is-a-copy/articleshow/11362761.cms |title=Pilla Chao is a copy |last=Kavirayani |first=Suresh |publisher=''The Times of India'' |date=4 January 2012 |accessdate=23 February 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223150629/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/tamil/movies/news/Pilla-Chao-is-a-copy/articleshow/11362761.cms |archivedate=23 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The makers violated the rules of The Cinematograph Act, 1952 and the Central Board of Film Certification regarding the re-working of its title from ''The Businessman'' to ''Businessman'' after the board cleared the film with the former title. The Andhra Pradesh Film Chamber of Commerce cleared the registration of the film title as ''The Businessman'' on 1 January 2011 through a letter and was renewed up to 22 April 2012. The set of posters sent to the board for certification purpose carried the full title. The film was publicised without the definite article, which was also missing from the posters. Also the 'A' certification was omitted.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/Businessman-throws-rules-to-the-winds/articleshow/11855200.cms |title='Businessman' throws rules to the winds |publisher=''The Times of India'' |date=12 February 2012 |accessdate=23 February 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223150628/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/Businessman-throws-rules-to-the-winds/articleshow/11855200.cms |archivedate=23 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} After release, the film was criticised for the usage of curse-words by the protagonist and a few intimate sequences between the lead pair. The muting of a few dialogues and blurring of a few visuals by the board were criticised by viewers.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/beeped-and-blurred/article2812502.ece|title=Beeped and blurred|last=Chowdary|first=Y. Sunita|publisher=''The Hindu''|date=19 January 2012|accessdate=23 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223150803/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/beeped-and-blurred/article2812502.ece|archivedate=23 February 2015}} [[Bajrang Dal]] lodged a complaint with Municipal police on 14 January 2012 stating that the lyrics of the song "We love Bad Boys" contained vulgar words and conveyed an unacceptable meaning for which they demanded action against Jagannadh. The police confirmed this and stated they would seek legal opinions for taking further action.{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/bad-words-get-businessman-in-trouble/220902-62-131.html|title=Bad words get 'Businessman' in trouble|publisher=IBN Live|date=14 January 2012|accessdate=23 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223153712/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/bad-words-get-businessman-in-trouble/220902-62-131.html|archivedate=23 February 2015}} [[Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad]] activists entered the Aradhana theatre at [[Tarnaka]] near [[Osmania University]], and stopped a screening on 25 January 2012 at 11:30 AM. They stole the film's reels and ripped off the film's hoardings and flexies at the theatre, protesting a few dialogues which allegedly demeaned [[Rama]] and were anti-patriotic.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/businessman-faces-abvps-ire/article2833390.ece|title=‘Businessman' faces ABVP's ire|publisher=''The Hindu''|date=26 January 2012|accessdate=23 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223150925/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/businessman-faces-abvps-ire/article2833390.ece|archivedate=23 February 2015}} They burnt the film's reels in front of [[Osmania Arts College]] in protest of the lyrics of the song "We want Bad Boys" alleging that the song was filled with abusive words. They also demanded a public apology by Mahesh and Jagannadh.{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/telugu/article336560.ece|title=‘Businessman’ reels burnt by ABVP men|publisher=''The New Indian Express''|date=26 January 2012|accessdate=23 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223150922/http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/telugu/article336560.ece|archivedate=23 February 2015}} Journalist Rohit Vats in his article ''Real and reel: How Telugu cinema celebrates stalking'' mentioned the sequences in ''Businessman'' quoting, "The conversation between Mahesh Babu and Kajal Aggarwal in Businessman was termed vulgar but later it was accepted in the name of sarcasm. Basically, it was perceived as harmless teasing".{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/regional/stalking-in-telugu-cinema-a-thing-of-the-popular-psyche/article1-1280156.aspx|title=Real and web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/article2800156.ece|title=A cool escape from reality, literally|last=Krishnamoorthy|first=Suresh|publisher=''The 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150222154329/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/article2800156.ece|archivedate=22 February 2015}} Y. Sunita Chowdary, also from ''The Hindu'', wrote "The ''Businessman'' has a mix of action, image, dialogue and montage but what makes it entertaining is that all the above quantities are inextricably bound and linked together at every level with an admirably tight script." She added that Jagannadh did not make any structural, technical or content errors, although the story was a regular one.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/article2798529.ece|title=The Businessman: Back in form|last=Chowdary|first=Y. Sunita|publisher=''The Hindu''|date=14 January 2012|accessdate=22 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150222154328/http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/article2798529.ece|archivedate=22 February 2015}} Suresh Kavirayani of ''[[The Times of India]]'' gave the film 3.25 out of 5 stars and called the film an "unpretentious entertainer that manages to strike the right balance", which according to him, had enough in it to keep the viewers interested till the end despite not being a spectacular production.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movie-reviews/Businessman/movie-review/11475984.cms |title=Businessman movie review |last=Kavirayani |first=Suresh |publisher=''The Times of India'' |date=14 January 2012 |accessdate=22 February 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6WXELTqhn?url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movie-reviews/Businessman/movie-review/11475984.cms |archivedate=22 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} {{rating|3.5|5|score=3.25/5 stars}} [[Indo-Asian News Service]] gave the film 3 out of 5 stars and called ''Businessman'' a film for Mahesh's fans and highlighted Mahesh's performance and Jagannadh's dialogues as the film's strong points.{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/telugu-review-businessman-is-a-must-watch/221104-62-131.html|title=Telugu Review: 'Businessman' a must watch for punchy dialogues, Mahesh's superb acting|author=IANS|publisher=IBN Live|date=15 January 2012|accessdate=22 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150222154518/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/telugu-review-businessman-is-a-must-watch/221104-62-131.html|archivedate=22 February 2015}} {{rating|3|5}} Another reviewer from IANS called the film "senseless yet entertaining" and stated "Mahesh's dashing performance as a mafia kingpin with a hidden personal agenda is commendable and deserves high appreciation. ''Businessman'' may be perverse and appeal only to the masses, yet is a winner for unexplainable reasons."{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/businessman-review-this-tamil-film-is-for-the-masses/309332-40.html|title='Businessman' Review: This Tamil film is for the masses|author=IANS|publisher=IBN Live|date=7 December 2012|accessdate=22 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150222154516/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/businessman-review-this-tamil-film-is-for-the-masses/309332-40.html|archivedate=22 February 2015}} Radhika Rajamani of [[Rediff.com]] gave the film 2.5 out of 5 stars and opined that ''Businessman'' was an entertaining film if watched uncritically. She added "There's no doubt that Puri Jagan has played to the gallery and kept the masses and Mahesh's image in mind while conceiving this film. It's just Mahesh all the way."{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/review/south-review-businessman-is-a-treat-for-mahesh-fans/20120113.htm|title=Review: Businessman is a treat for Mahesh fans|last=Rajamani|first=Radhika|publisher=Rediff.com|date=13 January 2012|accessdate=22 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150222154640/http://www.rediff.com/movies/review/south-review-businessman-is-a-treat-for-mahesh-fans/20120113.htm|archivedate=22 February 2015}} {{rating|2.5|5}} [[Sify]] felt that the film was strictly for Mahesh's fans but praised Jagannadh's work saying that the "story sounds far fetched, demanding logic. The screenplay is a saving grace, which works like magic, making the audiences forget the monotony in between." The reviewer highlighted Mahesh's performance, the dialogues and the songs as the film's stronger elements.{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/businessman-review-watch-it-for-mahesh-babu-s-sake-review-telugu-14988630.html|title=Businessman review: Watch it for Mahesh Babu`s sake|publisher=Sify|date=13 January 2012|accessdate=22 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150222154638/http://www.sify.com/movies/businessman-review-watch-it-for-mahesh-babu-s-sake-review-telugu-14988630.html|archivedate=22 February 2015}} Ramchander of [[Oneindia.in|Oneindia Entertainment]] called ''Businessman'' a serious film with limited appeal, which might be enjoyed by Mahesh's fans but which would be an average for others.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmibeat.com/telugu/reviews/2012/businessman-movie-review-130112.html|title=Businessman — Movie Review|author=Ramchander|publisher=Oneindia Entertainment|date=13 January 2012|accessdate=22 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150222154637/http://www.filmibeat.com/telugu/reviews/2012/businessman-movie-review-130112.html|archivedate=22 February 2015}} B. [[image:castlewalk.gif|thumb|Castle walk]] '''Castle Walk''' is a [[dance]] originated and made famous by [[Vernon and Irene Castle]]. The Castle Walk became popular through its introduction into the [[Tango (dance)|Tango]]. In this dance, the man continually goes forward and the lady backward. In order that the lady may be properly guided about the room, the man's arm encircles her just under her arm, while her left hand rests on the man's right arm. The position of the lady's right arm and the man's left arm is high, with their hands clasped, see the illustration.[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/musdi:@field(DOCID+@lit(M16127)) the description] from ''[[An American Ballroom Companion]]'' The man starts forward with his left foot and the lady backward with her right, simply walking with gliding steps keeping on the toes, one count of the music to each step. This step is continued to the end of the room, where a large circle is begun, which is gradually made smaller and smaller, until it is ended by whirling completely around three times, to three counts of the music and then dip. The Castle Walk may be varied by describing the figure eight or zig-zag instead of the large circle. To make the three whirls is rather a difficult matter, as it must be done very rapidly to accomplish a complete revolution to one beat of the music, but with a little practice it is soon learned. [[Troy Kinney]] describes the Castle Walk as part of [[One-Step]] as follows: [[Troy Kinney]], [[Margaret West Kinney]] (1914) "The Dance: Its Place in Art and Life" ([[public domain]], digitized by [[Google]])
This is a walking step of direct advance and retreat, not used to move to the side. The couple are in closed position, the woman, therefore, stepping backward as the man steps forward, and vice versa. The advancing foot is planted in fourth position, the knee straight, the toe down so that the ball of the foot strikes the floor first. The walk presents an appearance of strutting, although the shoulders are held level, and the body firm; a sharp twist that punctuates each step is effected by means of pivoting on the supporting foot. The shoulder and hip movements that originally characterised [[Turkey Trot (dance)|the "trot"]] are no longer practiced.
