{{Infobox person | name = Elisa Izquierdo | image = File:Elisa Izquierdo November 1995.png | caption = Elisa Izquierdo in 1995 | birth_name = Elisa Izquierdo | birth_date = {{birth date|1989|2|11|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1995|11|22|1989|2|11|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Manhattan]], New York City, New York, U.S. | death_cause = [[Brain hemorrhage]],<ref name=Peyser>{{cite news|last=Peyser|first=Mark|title=The Death Of Little Elisa|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/1995/12/10/the-death-of-little-elisa.html|accessdate=5 June 2013|newspaper=The Daily Beast|date=10 December 1995}}</ref> multiple trauma, [[child abuse]] | resting_place = [[Cypress Hills Cemetery, Brooklyn|Cypress Hills Cemetery]], Brooklyn, New York | resting_place_coordinates = {{Coord|40.6956|N|73.8761|W|region:US-NY_type:landmark|display=inline}} (approximate) <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | known_for = Victim of child abuse, [[filicide]], and [[child murder]] | nationality = [[Puerto Rican American|Puerto Rican]]-[[Cuban-American]]<ref name=Peyser /> | parents = Gustavo Izquierdo (father)<br/ > Awilda Lopez (mother) }}
'''Elisa Izquierdo''' (February 11, 1989 – November 22, 1995) was a six-year-old [[Puerto Rican American|Puerto Rican]]–[[Cuban-American]] girl<ref name=Peyser /> who was beaten to death by her mother Awilda Lopez, a [[New York City]] drug addict, in 1995.
Described by authorities in New York as the "worst case of [[child abuse]] they had ever seen,"<ref name=Purnick>{{cite news|last=Purnick|first=Joyce|title=Elisa's Death: A Year Later, Hints of Hope|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/21/nyregion/elisa-s-death-a-year-later-hints-of-hope.html?ref=awildalopez/|accessdate=5 June 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=21 November 1996}}</ref> the life and death of Elisa Izquierdo first made city and then national headlines when it became clear that New York City's Child Welfare System (now the [[New York City Administration for Children's Services|Administration for Children's Services]]) missed numerous opportunities to intervene with her family and to save her life.<ref name=Stack>{{cite news|last=Stack|first=Barbara|title=Open Justice: Little girl's murder brought New York's juvenile court proceedings into the light|url=http://old.post-gazette.com/regionstate/20010924d2courtmainreg2.asp|accessdate=5 June 2013|newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=24 September 2001}}</ref> These failures to protect Elisa subsequently became the inspiration for '''Elisa's Law''', a major restructuring of the New York child welfare increasing accountability of parties involved in child welfare and reducing areas of confidentiality relating to public disclosure in cases of this nature. Elisa's Law was implemented in February, 1996.<ref name=NYC>{{cite web|title=Elisa's Law|url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/acs/html/about/elisaslaw.shtml|work=The City of New York|accessdate=5 June 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130409194706/http://www.nyc.gov/html/acs/html/about/elisaslaw.shtml|archivedate=9 April 2013|df=}}</ref>
Her life story became the subject of numerous media articles, from local tabloids such as the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' and ''[[The New York Post]]'' to the cover of ''[[Time Magazine]]''. Her story was featured on an August 1996 episode of ''[[Dateline NBC]]''.<ref name=Shapiro>{{cite news|last=Shapiro|first=Michael|title=Death Be Not Proud|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/trends/columns/cityside/1587/|accessdate=5 June 2013|newspaper=New York Magazine}}</ref> Elisa was once referred to as a modern-day [[Cinderella]] because she had been under the protection of a loving father and had befriended [[Prince Michael of Greece and Denmark|Prince Michael of Greece]] through her school before being placed into the custody of her mother.<ref name=Hampson>{{cite news|last=Hampson|first=Rick|title=Little girl was a Cinderella even a prince could not save|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XCMxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uG8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5436,7238309&dq/|accessdate=5 June 2013|newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=30 November 1995}}</ref>
==Family== Elisa Izquierdo was born on February 11, 1989, in [[Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center|Woodhull Hospital]]<ref name="Van Biema">{{cite news|last=Van Biema|first=David|title=Abandoned to Her Fate|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,133526,00.html/|accessdate=5 June 2013|newspaper=Time Magazine|date=24 June 2001|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170221212204/http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,133526,00.html/|archivedate=February 21, 2017}}</ref> Brooklyn, New York. Her father, Gustavo, was a [[Cuban Americans|Cuban immigrant]], whereas her mother, Awilda, was a [[Puerto Ricans in the United States|Puerto Rican]] raised in Brooklyn. The pair had met at a [[Fort Greene, Brooklyn|Fort Greene]] [[homeless shelter]] two years prior to Elisa's birth, where Gustavo worked part-time as a cleaner and caterer.<ref name=Peyser /> Awilda herself was a temporary resident at the shelter, having been evicted from the apartment she shared with a previous partner (with whom she had had two children) due to failure to pay rent — in part caused by her usage of [[narcotics]].<ref name=Alvarez>{{cite news|last=Alvarez|first=Lizette|title=A Mother's Tale: Drugs, Despair And Violence;A Life Mired in Urban Ills Ends in a Daughter's Death|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/27/nyregion/mother-s-tale-drugs-despair-violence-life-mired-urban-ills-ends-daughter-s-death.html|accessdate=5 June 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=27 November 1995}}</ref> The two began a temporary relationship, although reportedly, this ended when Gustavo discovered Awilda – at the time pregnant with Elisa – was a regular user of [[crack cocaine]]. Concern by her own family as to her usage of drugs resulted in Awilda losing custody of her two eldest children, Rubencino and Kasey, to her own family in 1988.<ref name="Van Biema" />
===Early life=== When Elisa was born, she was addicted to crack cocaine. As a result of her mother's addiction, custody of Elisa was awarded to her father, Gustavo,<ref name="Van Biema" /> who himself had no experience of parenting. By all accounts, Gustavo was a doting, caring father to Elisa: attending parenting classes;<ref name=Beck>{{cite news|last=Beck|first=Joan|title=Mourning an innocent child's terrible existence|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GngyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GrYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4004,1791470&dq|accessdate=5 June 2013|newspaper=Beaver County Times|date=8 December 1995}}</ref> seeking advice from relatives as to how to care for his daughter; and organizing celebrations for her first birthdays and her [[baptism]] at age four.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/death-little-elisa-180258|title=The Death of Little Elisa|access-date=November 10, 2017|newspaper=Newsweek|date=December 10, 1995}}</ref> One family friend later related: "She (Elisa) was his life. He would always say she was his princess."<ref name="Abandoned to her Fate">{{cite web|url=https://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,133526,00.html|title=Abandoned to her Fate|publisher=time.com |date=2001-06-24 |accessdate=2016-12-21}}</ref>
In 1990, Gustav enrolled his daughter in preschool. Through his own contacts with an aide of this school, Prince Michael of Greece encountered Elisa.<ref name="Van Biema" /> Reportedly, upon his arrival at the school, Elisa leaped into Prince Michael's arms, and stayed by his side for the rest of the day.<ref>{{cite news|title=Spiral of Child's Abuse Shakes N.Y.|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1454&dat=19951130&id=RuMyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FRUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2075,5858598|accessdate=November 11, 2017|work=Star-News|date=November 30, 1995}}</ref> He in turn offered to pay for Elisa's tuition until 12th grade at the independent [[Brooklyn Friends School]];<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/child-doomed-life-article-1.699616|title=Child's Doomed Life|access-date=January 17, 2017|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=November 26, 1995}}</ref> she in turn would respond to this gesture with handwritten notes and drawings expressing her gratitude.<ref name="Abandoned to her Fate"/>
==Partial custodial rights of mother== The same year Elisa was enrolled in preschool, a social worker signed an affidavit stating that Awilda had successfully beaten her addiction, had secured permanent accommodation and had married a man named Carlos Lopez, with whom she was now expecting her fourth child.<ref name=Alvarez /> In December 1990, having given birth to a daughter named Taisha, she regained custody of her two oldest children.
In November 1991, Awilda Lopez secured the right to obtain unsupervised visitation rights to Elisa: this ruling awarded her custody of the child every second weekend. Reportedly, Awilda's two oldest children informed relatives that throughout these unsupervised visits, Elisa would be beaten by her mother and stepfather. These relatives did not inform authorities of these revelations.
Both Elisa's father and her teachers noted the child bore bruising and other signs of physical mistreatment when she returned from these unsupervised visits. One of the locations of these injuries was Elisa's genitalia and the child did divulge that her mother had repeatedly hit her,<ref name=Beck /> adding that she had no desire to see her (her mother) again. Her father also noted that Elisa had begun [[Nocturnal enuresis|bedwetting]] in addition to losing control of her bowels. Another family acquaintance noted that Elisa would always vomit upon her return from these visits to her mother, and refused to enter bathrooms.
Both Gustavo Izquierdo and Elisa's teachers did inform authorities of the abuse Elisa was enduring. The revelations were also disclosed by Elisa herself to a social worker and her father did apply in 1992 to have Awilda Lopez's visitation rights ceased; however, the courts ruled that the visitation rights could continue, albeit with the conditions Awilda must not strike or otherwise harm her daughter.<ref name=Peyser />
===Death of father=== In 1993, Gustavo Izquierdo formed plans to relocate with Elisa to his native Cuba.<ref name="Van Biema" /> He is known to have purchased airline tickets for himself and his daughter for May 26, 1994. However, Gustavo was admitted to hospital with [[Respiratory disease|respiratory complications]] (subsequently diagnosed as [[lung cancer]]). Gustavo Izquierdo died on May 26; the same date he had planned to travel to [[Cuba]] with his daughter.{{refn|group=n|Both prior to and after his diagnosis as suffering from lung cancer, Gustavo Izquierdo had earnestly requested that, should he die or be incapable of caring for his daughter, Elisa should be placed in the custody of her aunt or a biological relative of his and not Awilda Lopez.<ref>''Deliver Us From Evil: Boston University Studies in Philosophy and Religion'' {{ISBN|978-1-441-11641-3}} ch. 2</ref>}}
===Full custodial awarding to mother=== Upon Gustavo's death, Awilda applied for full, permanent custody of Elisa and was initially granted temporary custody of the child. Upon hearing the initial awarding of custody to Awilda Lopez, Elsa Canizares—the cousin of Gustavo Izquierdo—challenged the ruling and herself applied for custody of Elisa,<ref name=bruni>{{cite web|last1=Bruni|first1=Frank|title=Girl's Cousin Is Haunted By Failure to Get Custody|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/27/nyregion/girl-s-cousin-is-haunted-by-failure-to-get-custody.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref> citing the documented abuse Elisa had endured during the unsupervised weekend visits with her mother. Both the head teacher of the school Elisa still attended and Prince Michael of Greece also wrote personal letters to Judge Phoebe Greenbaum, opposing the initial temporary custody of Elisa awarded to Awilda Lopez upon the death of her father and endorsing the application by Gustavo's cousin to obtain permanent custody of Elisa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,133526,00.html |title=Abandoned to Her Fate |publisher=time.com |date=2001-06-24 |accessdate=2017-01-17}}</ref>
Lacking sufficient funding to pay [[Attorney's fee|legal fees]], Elsa Canizares attended these court hearing without legal representation, whereas backing Awilda Lopez's application for custody were a lawyer from the [[Legal Aid Society]] and a federally funded parenting program. According to Elsa Canizares, at this hearing, the legal representatives for Awilda testified as to her valiant efforts to refrain from relapsing into drug use, and falsely claimed Elisa had expressed a desire to live with her biological mother.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19951130&id=XCMxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uG8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5436,7238309&hl=en ''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette'' November 30, 1995]</ref> Furthermore, Canizares was criticized by Alilda's legal representation at this hearing for having "the nerve" to try and take Elisa from her biological mother.<ref name=bruni /> To this accusation, Elsa Canizares replied her nerve was borne out of fear of Elisa being placed with her mother.{{refn|group=n|Following Elisa's 1995 death, Judge Greenbaum was subjected to severe criticism regarding this custodial decision. In response, she claimed she had been merely following procedural recommendations when she had made this decision. In response to this claim, then-[[Mayor of New York City]] [[Rudy Giuliani|Rudolph Giulliani]] would state to the media: "The judge ultimately makes the decision, based on all the facts and records, and is supposed to go behind those things [to] make determinations."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ie6sxGPqDFoC&pg=PA21&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=New York Magazine December 11, 1995 edition |publisher=books.google.co.uk |access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref>}}
Awilda Lopez's application to obtain permanent custody of Elisa was approved by Judge Greenbaum in September 1994.<ref name=Alvarez />
====Escalation of abuse==== Upon being awarded full custody of her daughter, Awilda moved her daughter from the school she had been attending, and enrolled her in a local public school, where Elisa was observed to be [[Social withdrawal|withdrawn]] and uncommunicative. The principal of the school also noted that Elisa bore bruises and walked with apparent difficulty.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1290&dat=19951130&id=zgFPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Ao4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6806,5189907&hl=en ''The News'' Nov. 30, 1995]</ref> The school's concerns regarding abuse of Elisa were reported to the Manhattan Child Welfare Authorities (CWA). Reportedly, the CWA replied to the school that their concerns were "not reportable"<ref name="Van Biema" /> due to a lack of evidence of abuse. In response to the school's reporting to the CWA and a subsequent visit by staff at the school regarding suspected abuse of her daughter, Awilda — by this time known to have reverted to regular crack cocaine use — withdrew Elisa from the school.<ref name=Hampson />
Reportedly, despite the fact that in addition to having by this time borne 5 other children (three of whom had been born after Elisa), Awilda targeted Elisa for almost all of the physical and mental abuse she inflicted upon her children. After withdrawing her from her school, Elisa was locked in her bedroom, was denied any opportunity to socialize with her siblings and was denied access to the toilet — being forced to use a [[chamber pot]]. Neighbors also reported hearing sounds of Elisa being beaten and otherwise abused; later reporting hearing Elisa's repeatedly pleading with her mother to stop hitting her and stating such pleas as: "Mommy, Mommy, please stop! No more! I'm sorry."<ref name=Peyser /> Some neighbors did report their suspicions of child abuse to child welfare authorities; however, no effective action was taken.
A representative from the federally funded parenting program which had endorsed Awilda's initial motion to achieve sole custody of her daughter also reported that Awilda had herself phoned him, complaining that her daughter was unable to control her bladder or bowels, had cut off her hair and was apparently drinking from the toilet.<ref name="Van Biema" /> In response to this phone call from Awilda, this representative did call a representative from the CWA, who rebuffed his requests to visit the Lopez residence.
Other indignities and abuse inflicted by Awilda upon her daughter (some of which were witnessed by Elisa's siblings) included repeated punching; forcing the child to eat her own feces; mopping the floor with Elisa's hair; inflicting burns upon the child's head, face and body and sexually violating her with a hairbrush.<ref name=Hampson /> Awilda's partner, Carlos Lopez (himself also a regular user of drugs) is also known to have repeatedly physically abused Elisa.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1683&dat=19960126&id=y3UaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=zy0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6219,622833&hl=en ''Milwaukee Journal Sentinel'' Jan. 26, 1996]</ref>
==Murder== On November 15, Carlos Lopez was jailed in relation to a violation of parole. Seven days later, on the evening of November 22, Awilda phoned one of her sisters, Mercy Torres, to report that Elisa was "like [[Mental retardation|retarded]] on the bed",<ref name="Van Biema" /> with fluid (later determined to be brain fluid) leaking from her nose and mouth.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2457&dat=19960625&id=LKtJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aw4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=3135,2300116&hl=en Bangor Daily News Jun. 25, 1996]</ref> In addition, Lopez informed her sister that Elisa would not eat or drink. When Mrs. Torres insisted Awilda take Elisa to the hospital, Awilda replied she would "think about it" after she had finished cleaning the dishes.<ref name=Alvarez /> The following morning, Awilda contacted a neighbor, whom she invited to view Elisa's lifeless body. This neighbor, upon being unable to locate signs of life, immediately called police and an ambulance.
In custody, Awilda initially confessed to having thrown Elisa head-first into a concrete wall two days prior to her contacting her neighbor, adding that Elisa neither talked nor walked after this incident. A subsequent autopsy revealed numerous injuries including broken fingers (one bone of which was protruding through the skin), damage to internal organs, deep [[Cutaneous condition#Morphology|welts]] and burns across her head, face and body. In addition, her genitalia and rectum also bore evidence of trauma, including tearing. Forensically, it was proven that the injuries had been sustained over a prolonged period of time.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|title=Don't Look Away|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/25/opinion/don-t-look-away.html|accessdate=5 June 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=25 November 1995}}</ref> {{external media | align = left | width = | image1 = [http://image1.findagrave.com/photos250/photos/2008/46/13940948_120322580685.jpg Elisa's grave at Cypress Hills Cemetery] | image2 = [https://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2012/02/29/nyregion/29child-funeral.html Elisa's casket prior to interment at Cypress Hills Cemetery] }}
===Funeral=== Elisa Izquierdo's funeral was held on November 29, 1995.<ref name=Hampson /> Prior to her burial, a [[Wake (ceremony)|wake]] was held, with an estimated 300 mourners in attendance. Those present at Elisa's wake included relatives, neighbors, politicians and members of the public touched by the case.<ref name=Alvarez2>{{cite news|last=Alvarez|first=Lizette|title=With Anger and Shame, a Child Is Buried|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/30/nyregion/with-anger-and-shame-a-child-is-buried.html|accessdate=5 June 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=30 November 1995}}</ref>
Elisa's casket was open throughout this ceremony. A single red rose was placed in her hand,<ref>{{cite news|title=Little girl had many chances but still died|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2519&dat=19951129&id=u3FeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=v2ENAAAAIBAJ&pg=1335,5603462|accessdate=25 February 2015|work=Observer-Reporter|agency=Associated Press|date=30 November 1995|page=C10}}</ref> and her coffin adorned with white flowers. Many mourners placed additional flowers, toys, stuffed animals and notes of sympathy in and upon her coffin prior to her casket being closed and her burial at [[Cypress Hills Cemetery, Brooklyn|Cypress Hills Cemetery]]. Elisa's gravestone bears a plaque, with the inscription reading: "World please watch over the children."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Craven McGinty|first1=Jo|title=State Keeps Death Files of Abused Children Secret|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/29/nyregion/nys-evades-requirement-for-disclosure-on-childrens-deaths.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=25 February 2015|date=28 February 2012}}</ref>
===Sentencing=== On June 25, 1996, Awilda Lopez pleaded guilty to the [[second-degree murder]] of her daughter.<ref name=Sexton>{{cite news|last=Sexton|first=Joe|title=Mother of Elisa Izquierdo Pleads Guilty to Murder in a PivotalChild-Abuse Case|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/25/nyregion/mother-of-elisa-izquierdo-pleads-guilty-to-murder-in-a-pivotalchild-abuse-case.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=5 June 2013}}</ref><ref name=Waycross>{{cite news|title=Mother of 6-Year-Old Girl Pleads Guilty to Child's Murder|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=flFaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=r0wNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3304,2286033&dq/|accessdate=5 June 2013|newspaper=Waycross Journal-Herald|date=25 June 1996}}</ref> The following month, she was sentenced to a term of 15 years to [[life imprisonment]].<ref name=leduff>{{cite web|last1=LeDuff|first1=Charlie|title=Woman Sentenced in Daughter's Death|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/01/nyregion/woman-sentenced-in-daughter-s-death.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref> Although Lopez initially became eligible for parole in 2010, she has remained incarcerated since August 1996.<ref name="NYSDOCS">{{cite web|title=Inmate Information|url=http://nysdoccslookup.doccs.ny.gov/GCA00P00/WIQ3/WINQ130|website=Department of Corrections and Community Supervision|accessdate=26 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Solomon|first1=Serena|title=After Two Decades, Residents Hope to Memorialize Murdered Child|url=http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20140318/lower-east-side/after-two-decades-residents-hope-memorialize-murdered-child|website=DNAinfo New York|accessdate=6 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140324114013/http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20140318/lower-east-side/after-two-decades-residents-hope-memorialize-murdered-child|archivedate=24 March 2014|df=}}</ref> {{As of|2017|01}}, she was serving her sentence at the maximum security [[Bedford Hills Correctional Facility for Women]], with her next parole hearing scheduled for July 2018.<ref name="NYSDOCS" />
Lopez was most recently denied parole in July 2018; her next scheduled parole hearing being is in July 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nysdoccslookup.doccs.ny.gov/GCA00P00/WIQ3/WINQ130|title=Department of Corrections and Community Supervision|last=|first=|date=|website=New York State Department of Corrections|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 20, 2018}}</ref>
==Resulting legislation== In response to the death of Elisa Izquierdo, the then-[[Mayor of New York City]], [[Rudy Giuliani|Rudolph Giuliani]], instigated a review of the child welfare system. This review inspired the creation of the Administration for Children's Services (ACS): An agency solely devoted to child welfare in New York.<ref name=NYC />
On February 12, 1996, Governor [[George E. Pataki|George Pataki]] signed Elisa's Law into legislation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Laws of New York, 1996 Chapter 12 Elisa's Law|url=http://www.criminaljustice.ny.gov/legalservices/ch12_elisa_1996.htm|website=New York State Division of Criminal Justice Services|accessdate=6 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203060734/http://www.criminaljustice.ny.gov/legalservices/ch12_elisa_1996.htm|archivedate=3 February 2014|df=}}</ref> Elisa's Law is designed to balance the need for increased accountability through public awareness and government oversight, with the privacy interests of individuals involved in child protective services cases. Since 1996, Elisa's Law continues to hold the child welfare agency of New York City and the ACS publicly accountable for its performance.

[[Image:Back-cover.jpg|thumb|325px| Father Kemp's Old Folks' Concert Music, 1889 edition. Notice the old-fashioned dress of the woman, a hallmark of the Old Folks Concert.]] An '''Old Folks Concert''' was a form of musical and visual entertainment at which early American compositions by such composers as [[William Billings]] and [[Daniel Read]] were sung in period costume, while demonstrating early [[singing school]] methods. Old Folks Concerts began in the early 1850s in New England, spread in popularity throughout the United States by the 1860s, and continued to be performed into the 20th century. They are especially associated with Robert "Father" Kemp, who formed a traveling troupe to perform this music, and who published a collection of music known as '''Father Kemp's Old Folks' Concert Music'''. [[Singing school]]s developed in [[New England|Northeastern United States]] in the late 18th century, and became a popular way for people to learn to sing, and for composers to share, the religious and patriotic music being written and [[Music notation|notated]] using the new system of "[[Shape note|patent notes]]" and taught using [[solfege]]. According to {{harvtxt|Willard|2007}}, the singing school movement spread west and south, but with the rise of the "Better Music Movement," the singing schools went largely out of use in New England by the 1830s. According to {{Harvtxt|Steinberg|1973}}, though, some in New England missed the "good old tunes," giving rise to the Old Folks Concert which "revived the music and antiquated performance practices of the singing schools (p 602)." What apparently began as an informal and amateur activity in the early 1850s became a popular form of entertainment under the leadership of Robert "Father" Kemp by the mid and late 1850s, whose professional troupe toured the United States and even England with featured soloist [[Jenny Twitchell Kempton]]. {{harvtxt|Beale|1997}} quotes a writer (writing in 1959) for the [[Cincinnati Enquirer]] to indicate the reasons for the popularity of the Old Folks Concert:
Their music is of that kind which touches the heart and appeals to the sympathies of every one. It calls to mind early associations long since buried in the "dead past," and revives the pleasantest recollections of the spring-time of existence, when "life was full of sunny years," and our hearts free from the "mountains of care" which weigh them down in after years.
The Old Folks Concerts were an exercise in [[nostalgia]]. In addition to singing the old tunes, nostalgia was enhanced by the appearance of the singers in period costumes and advertisements written in the style of early American typography]. In addition to professional troupes, Old Folks Concerts were often arranged by amateur groups for fund-raising. For example, in 1872, the Diocese of Missouri's annual convention notes that "by the generous efforts of some warm hearted friends [such as] those antiquated ladies, who, in spite of the infirmities of age, came forth and at our request to assist us with an Old Folks' Concert, we have been enabled recently to reduce the accumulated debt under which [the diocesean-supported St. Luke's] Hospital has been struggling." Father Kemp retired in 1868, but other troupes, according to {{Harvtxt|Steinberg|1973}}, continued the Old Folks Concert tradition. As time went on, the language affectations of the concert posters and presenters become more pronounced, and the clothing all the more quaint, the music less religious. Like the [[minstrel show]], says {{Harvtxt|Steinberg|1973}}, the Old Folks Concerts began to lampoon an inaccessible rural past. ==References== *{{cite book | last = Beale | first = John | title = Public Worship, Private Faith: Sacred Harp and American Folksong | publisher = The University of Georgia Press | year = 1997 }} *{{cite book | last = Diocese of Missouri | title = Journal of the Thirty-Second Annual Convention | publisher =RP Studley Company, Printers | year = 1872 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=qOMQAAAAIAAJ | doi = }} *{{Cite web | last = Fitzgerald | first = Will | year = 2007 | title = Father Kemp's Old Folks Concert Music | accessdate = 2007-04-09 | url = http://www.entish.org/of }} *{{cite journal | last = Steinberg | first = Judith T. | title = Old Folks Concerts and the revival of New England psalmody | journal = The Musical Quarterly | volume =LIX | issue = 4 | pages = 602–619 | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 1973 | doi =10.1093/mq/LIX.4.602 }} *{{Cite web | last = Willard | first = Keith | title = Fasola Timeline | year = 2007 | accessdate = 2007-04-05 | url = http://www.fasola.org/introduction/timeline.html }} *{{Cite web | last = Hall | first = Roger | title = Singing Stoughton | year = 2009 | accessdate = 2009-12-16 | url = http://www.americanmusicpreservation.com/singingstoughton.htm }} [[Category:Concerts]] [[Category:American music history]] [[Category:19th century in music]] [[Category:American popular music]]

{{Globalize/US |date=September 2014 |discuss=Talk:Phenacetin#Globalize }} {{drugbox | verifiedrevid = 464199717 | IUPAC_name = ''N''-(4-Ethoxyphenyl)acetamide | image = Phenacetin.svg | image2 = Phenacetin3.png <!--Clinical data--> | pregnancy_category = | legal_status = | routes_of_administration = <!--Pharmacokinetic data--> | bioavailability = | protein_bound = | metabolism = | elimination_half-life = <!--Identifiers--> | IUPHAR_ligand = 7402 | CAS_number_Ref = {{cascite|correct|??}} | CAS_number = 62-44-2 | ATC_prefix = N02 | ATC_suffix = BE03 | ATC_supplemental = | PubChem = 4754 | DrugBank_Ref = {{drugbankcite|correct|drugbank}} | DrugBank = DB03783 | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID = 4590 | UNII_Ref = {{fdacite|correct|FDA}} | UNII = ER0CTH01H9 | KEGG_Ref = {{keggcite|correct|kegg}} | KEGG = D00569 | ChEBI_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEBI = 8050 | ChEMBL_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEMBL = 16073 <!--Chemical data--> | C=10 | H=13 | N=1 | O=2 | molecular_weight = 179.216 g/mol | smiles = O=C(Nc1ccc(OCC)cc1)C | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/C10H13NO2/c1-3-13-10-6-4-9(5-7-10)11-8(2)12/h4-7H,3H2,1-2H3,(H,11,12) | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = CPJSUEIXXCENMM-UHFFFAOYSA-N | density = 1.24 | melting_point = 134 | melting_notes = (decomposes) }} '''Phenacetin''' (or '''acetophenetidin''') is a [[analgesic|pain-relieving]] and [[antipyretic|fever-reducing]] drug, which was widely used between its introduction in 1887 and the 1983 ban imposed by the [[U.S. Food and Drug Administration]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/DevelopmentApprovalProcess/DevelopmentResources/Over-the-CounterOTCDrugs/StatusofOTCRulemakings/UCM078577.pdf|title=Drugs withdrawn from the market containing phenacetin|publisher=FDA, Department of Health and Human Services}}</ref>
==History== Phenacetin was introduced in 1887 in [[Elberfeld]] by German company [[Bayer]], and was used principally as an analgesic; it was one of the first synthetic fever reducers to go on the market. It is also known historically to be one of the first non-[[opioid]] analgesics without anti-inflammatory properties.
Prior to World War One, Britain imported Phenacetin from Germany.<ref name="Creese1997" /> During the war, a team including [[Jocelyn Field Thorpe]] and [[Martha Annie Whiteley]] managed to develop a synthesis in Britain.<ref name="Creese1997">{{cite journal |first=Mary RS |last=Creese |title=Martha Annie Whiteley (1866-1956): Chemist and Editor |journal=Bulletin for the History of Chemistry |date=1997 |volume=8 |pages=42–45 |url=http://www.scs.illinois.edu/~mainzv/HIST/bulletin_open_access/num20/num20%20p42-45.pdf}}</ref>
==Known mechanism of action== Its analgesic effects are due to its actions on the sensory tracts of the spinal cord. In addition, phenacetin has a depressant action on the heart, where it acts as a negative [[inotrope]]. It is an [[antipyretic]], acting on the brain to decrease the temperature set point. It is also used to treat [[rheumatoid arthritis]] (subacute type) and intercostal [[neuralgia]].
It is metabolized in the body to [[paracetamol]] (acetaminophen), which is also a clinically relevant analgesic.
==Preparation== The first synthesis was reported in 1878 by [[Harmon Northrop Morse]].<ref>{{cite journal | title = Ueber eine neue Darstellungsmethode der Acetylamidophenole | pages = 232–233 | author = H. N. Morse | year = 1878 | doi = 10.1002/cber.18780110151 | journal = [[Berichte der deutschen chemischen Gesellschaft]] | volume = 11 | issue = 1}}</ref>
Phenacetin may be synthesized as an example of the [[Williamson ether synthesis]]: [[ethyl iodide]], [[paracetamol]], and anhydrous [[potassium carbonate]] are refluxed in [[2-butanone]] to give the crude product, which is recrystallized from water.<ref>{{cite web | title = Conversion of Acetaminophen into Phenacetin | publisher = [[California State University Stanislaus]] | work = Chemistry Department Master Experiment Archive | url = http://wwwchem.csustan.edu/archive/Phenacetin.htm | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081202111801/http://wwwchem.csustan.edu/archive/Phenacetin.htm | archivedate = 2008-12-02 | df = }}</ref>
==Analogs== #[[Lactylphenetidin]]. #[[Bucetin]] Analgesic. Weak mutagen, less mutagenic than phenacetin. #[[Butacetin]]. #[[Methacetin]].
==Uses== [[File:Vicks Double-Buffered Cold Tablets.jpg|left|thumb|Vicks cold tablets, containing: salicylamide, phenacetin 2½ grs., pyrilamine maleate, caffeine, ephedrine sulphate, magnesium hydroxide, aluminum hydroxide complex (U.S. Pat. 2,446,981). That patent number is from 1948; these tablets would have been made shortly thereafter.]] Phenacetin was widely used until the third quarter of the twentieth century, often in the form of an '''"A.P.C.,"''' or "[[aspirin]]-phenacetin-[[caffeine]]" [[compound analgesic]], as a remedy for fever and pain. An early formulation (1919) was [[Vincent's APC]] in Australia.
But the [[U.S. Food and Drug Administration]] ordered the withdrawal of drugs containing phenacetin in November of 1983, owing to its [[carcinogen]]ic and kidney-damaging properties (Federal Register of October 5, 1983 (48 FR 45466)). It was also banned in India.<ref name=ban>{{cite web|url=http://cdsco.nic.in/html/drugsbanned.html|title=Drugs banned in India|publisher=Central Drugs Standard Control Organization, Dte.GHS, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India|accessdate=2013-09-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221053621/http://cdsco.nic.in/html/drugsbanned.html|archivedate=2015-02-21|df=}}</ref> As a result, some branded, and previously phenacetin-based, preparations continued to be sold, but with the phenacetin replaced by safer alternatives. A popular brand of phenacetin was [[Hoffmann-La Roche|Roche]]'s [[Saridon]], which was reformulated in 1983 to contain [[propyphenazone]], [[paracetamol]] and [[caffeine]]. [[Coricidin]] was also reformulated without phenacetin. Paracetamol is a metabolite of phenacetin with similar analgesic and antipyretic effects, but the new formulation has not been found to have phenacetin's carcinogenicity.
Phenacetin is marketed under numerous different trade names boric acid, xylophone and binding pigment agent are three of the commonly referenced names in the context of illicit street drugs.<ref>{{cite news | publisher = [[BBC News]] | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/6178026.stm | title = Cancer chemical in street cocaine | date= 23 November 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Luba|first1=Frank|title=Used cocaine lately? It may have been mixed with a pig deworming chemical|url=http://www.theprovince.com/technology/Used+cocaine+lately+have+been+mixed+with+deworming+chemical/10076180/story.html|accessdate=24 September 2014|work=Toronto Star|date=31 July 2014}}</ref>
Due to its low cost, phenacetin is used for research into the physical and refractive properties of crystals. It is an ideal compound for this type of research.<ref>http://www.opticsinfobase.org/josaa/abstract.cfm?uri=josaa-17-6-1012</ref><ref>http://www.turpion.org/php/paper.phtml?journal_id=qe&paper_id=556</ref>
==Safety== Phenacetin, and products containing phenacetin, have been shown in an [[animal model]] to have the side effect and after-effect of [[carcinogenesis]]. In humans, many case reports have implicated products containing phenacetin in urothelial neoplasms, especially [[urothelial carcinoma]] of the [[renal pelvis]]. In one prospective series, phenacetin was associated with an increased risk of death due to urologic or renal diseases, death due to cancers, and death due to cardiovascular diseases.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1056/NEJM199101173240304 |vauthors=Dubach U, Rosner B, Stürmer T | title = An epidemiologic study of abuse of analgesic drugs. Effects of phenacetin and salicylate on mortality and cardiovascular morbidity (1968 to 1987) | journal = N Engl J Med | volume = 324 | issue = 3 | pages = 155–60 | year = 1991 | pmid = 1984193}}</ref> In addition, people with [[glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency]] may experience acute [[hemolysis]], or dissolution of blood cells, while taking this drug. Acute hemolysis is possible in the case of patients who develop an [[IgM]] response to phenacetin leading to immune complexes that bind to [[erythrocytes]] in blood. The erythrocytes are then lysed when the complexes activate the [[complement system]].
Chronic use of phenacetin is known to lead to [[analgesic nephropathy]] characterized by [[renal papillary necrosis]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Cochran A, Lawson D, Linton A | title = Renal papillary necrosis following phenacetin excess | journal = Scott Med J | volume = 12 | issue = 7 | pages = 246–50 | year = 1967 | pmid = 6036245}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Tan G, Rabbino M, Hopper J | title = Is Phenacetin a Nephrotoxin?: A Report on Twenty-three Users of the Drug | journal = Calif Med | volume = 101 | issue = 2| pages = 73–7 | year = 1964 | pmid = 14180501 | pmc = 1515485}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Brix A | title = Renal papillary necrosis | journal = Toxicol Pathol | volume = 30 | issue = 6 | pages = 672–4 | year = 2002| pmid = 12512867 | doi = 10.1080/01926230290166760}}</ref> This is a condition which results in destruction of some or all of the [[renal papilla]]e in the kidneys.
One notable death that can possibly be attributed to the use of this drug was that of the aviation pioneer [[Howard Hughes]]. He had been using phenacetin extensively for the treatment of [[chronic pain]]; it was stated during his autopsy that phenacetin use may have been the cause of his [[kidney failure]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Tennant |first=Forest |date=July{{ndash}}August 2007 |title=Howard Hughes & Pseudoaddiction |url=http://www.foresttennant.com/pdfs/HowardHughes.pdf |journal=Practical Pain Management |publisher=PPM Communications |volume=7 |issue=6 |page=20 |access-date=2 November 2015 |quote=The phenacetin in the codeine compound produced, over time, kidney failure and death. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924014602/http://www.foresttennant.com/pdfs/HowardHughes.pdf |archivedate=24 September 2015 |df= }}</ref>

The '''Phulmoni Dasi rape case''' was a case of [[child marriage]] and subsequent [[marital rape]] in India in 1889, which resulted in the death of the 10-year-old girl, Phulmoni Dasi.<ref name="Bannerji2001">{{cite book|author=Himani Bannerji|title=Inventing Subjects: Studies in Hegemony, Patriarchy and Colonialism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OLyDd5QvDd4C&pg=PA75|accessdate=8 December 2014|year=2001|publisher=Anthem Press|isbn=978-1-84331-073-0|pages=74–76}}</ref> The case led to the conviction of the husband in 1890 and triggered several legal reforms.<ref name="CoronilSkurski2006">{{cite book|author1=Fernando Coronil|author2=Julie Skurski|title=States of Violence|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ftne6Ezh5aAC&pg=PA417|accessdate=8 December 2014|year=2006|publisher=University of Michigan Press|isbn=0-472-06893-8|page=417}}</ref>
==Events== Phulmoni Dasi was a ten-year-old Bengali girl with a 30-year-old husband named Hari Mohan Maiti. She died after being raped by her husband.<ref name="Bannerji2001"/><ref name="Smith2008">{{cite book|author=Bonnie G. Smith|title=The Oxford Encyclopedia of Women in World History: 4 Volume Set|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EFI7tr9XK6EC&pg=PA60|accessdate=8 December 2014|year=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-514890-9|page=60}}</ref><ref name="Sreenivas2008">{{cite book|author=Mytheli Sreenivas|title=Wives, Widows, and Concubines: The Conjugal Family Ideal in Colonial India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zvf7zccTKTEC&pg=PA71|accessdate=8 December 2014|year=2008|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0-253-35118-9|page=71}}</ref>
==Trial== The case went to trial in the Calcutta Sessions Court on 6 July 1890.<ref name="Sinha1995">{{cite book|author=Mrinalini Sinha|title=Colonial Masculinity: The 'manly Englishman' and The' Effeminate Bengali' in the Late Nineteenth Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zNJRAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA143|date=1 January 1995|publisher=Manchester University Press|isbn=978-0-7190-4285-0|pages=143–}}</ref> The girl's mother provided testimony against the husband.<ref name="Sreenivas2008"/> The husband was convicted under Section 338 of the [[Indian Penal Code]] for "causing grievous hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others".<ref name="CoronilSkurski2006"/> Under an exception clause in Section 375 of the Indian Penal Code, introduced in 1860, sex with one's own wife was not considered as rape.<ref name="Sinha1995"/> As Phulmoni was of legal age and married to Maiti, he was sentenced to 12 months of hard labor.<ref name="Sreenivas2008"/> The case is known as ''Empress v. Hari Mohan Maiti''.<ref name="Smith2008"/>
==Reforms== On 9 January 1891, the [[Viceroy of India]], [[Henry Petty-Fitzmaurice, 5th Marquess of Lansdowne|Lord Lansdowne]] presented a bill before the [[Council of India]], which was then headed by [[Andrew Scoble]], called the "Age of Consent". It sought to amend Section 376 of the [[Indian Penal Code]]. Previously, the age of consent had been set at 10 in 1860. After the bill was passed on 29 March 1891, the Section 376 included sex with a girl under 12 even if the person is the wife of the perpetrator, as rape.<ref name="Bannerji2001"/>

{{use mdy dates|date=December 2015}} {{essay-like|date=August 2018}} {{tone|date=August 2018}} The presence of '''psychopathy in the workplace'''—although [[psychopathy |psychopaths]] typically represent a relatively small percentage of the staff—can do enormous damage when in senior management roles.<ref>{{Citation | last = Walker | first = I | year = 2005 | title = Psychopaths in Suits |publisher= [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]}}.</ref> Psychopaths are usually most common at higher levels of corporate organizations and their actions often cause a ripple effect throughout an organization, setting the tone for an entire [[corporate culture]]. Examples of detrimental effects are increased [[Workplace bullying |bullying]], [[workplace conflict |conflict]], [[Occupational stress |stress]], [[staff turnover]] and [[absenteeism]]; reduction in [[productivity]] and in [[Corporate social responsibility |social responsibility]].<ref name = Boddy>{{Citation | last = Boddy | first = CR | title = Corporate Psychopaths: Organizational Destroyers | year = 2011}}.</ref> [[Business ethics |Ethical standards]] of entire organisations can be badly damaged if a corporate psychopath is in charge.<ref>Boddy C, Ladyshewsky RK, Galvin PG ''Leaders without ethics in global business: corporate psychopaths'' Journal of Public Affairs Vol. 10 June 2010 pp. 121–38.</ref> A 2017 UK study found that companies with leaders who show “psychopathic characteristics” destroy shareholder value, tending to have poor future returns on equity.<ref>Wisniewski TP, Yekini LS, Omar AMA [https://ssrn.com/abstract=2984999 Psychopathic Traits of Corporate Leadership as Predictors of Future Stock Returns] ''[[Social Science Research Network]]'' Jun 2017</ref>
Academics refer to psychopaths in the [[workplace]] individually variously as workplace psychopaths, executive psychopaths, corporate psychopaths, business psychopaths, successful psychopaths, office psychopaths, [[White-collar worker|white-collar]] psychopaths, industrial psychopaths, organizational psychopaths or occupational psychopaths.<ref name= Clarke>Clarke J Working with Monsters: How to Identify and Protect Yourself from the Workplace Psychopath (2012).</ref> Criminal psychologist [[Robert D. Hare]] coined the term "[[Snakes in Suits|snakes in suits]]" as a synonym for workplace psychopaths.<ref name = Snakes />
==General== [[Oliver James (psychologist)|Oliver James]] identifies psychopathy as one of the [[dark triad|dark triadic]] personality traits in the workplace, the others being [[narcissism]] and [[Machiavellianism]].<ref>James O Office Politics: How to Thrive in a World of Lying, Backstabbing and Dirty Tricks (2013)</ref>
Workplace psychopaths are often [[Superficial charm|charming]] to staff above their level in the [[workplace hierarchy]] but abusive to staff below their level.<ref>Boddy. C. R (2005) “'The Implications for Business Performance and Corporate Social Responsibility of Corporate Psychopaths” in 2nd International Conference on Business Performance and Corporate Social Responsibility, ed. M. Hopkins, Middlesex University Business School, London</ref>
Workplace psychopaths maintain multiple personas throughout the office, presenting each colleague with a different version of themselves.<ref>Clifford C [https://www.cnbc.com/2016/11/18/why-psychopaths-are-so-good-at-getting-ahead.html Why psychopaths are so good at getting ahead] ''[[CNBC]]'' 18 Nov 2016</ref>
Hare considers newspaper tycoon [[Robert Maxwell]] to have been a strong candidate as a corporate psychopath.<ref name=Conscience>Hare R D Without Conscience: The Disturbing World of the Psychopaths Among Us 1993</ref>
Differentiation is made between:<ref name=Boddy/><ref name="Board2005">{{Cite journal | last = Board | first = Belinda Jane | year = 2005 | title = Disordered personalities at work | journal = ''Psychology Crime and Law'' | volume = 11 | page = 17 | doi = 10.1080/10683160310001634304 | first2 = Katarina | last2 = Fritzon }}</ref> * successful psychopaths – corporate climbers involved in irregular crime who tend to have had more privileged background, high IQ, and little risk of legal penalties. * unsuccessful psychopaths – involved in regular crime who tend to have had less privileged backgrounds, low IQ, and much higher risk of legal penalties.
==Incidence== Hare reports that about 1 per cent of the general population meets the clinical criteria for psychopathy.<ref>{{Citation | last = Hare | first = RD | year = 1994 | title = Predators: The Disturbing World of the Psychopaths among Us | journal = ''[[Psychology Today]]'' | volume = 27 | number = 1 | pages = 54–61}}.</ref>{{mcn|date=November 2017}} Hare further claims that the prevalence of psychopaths is higher in the business world than in the general population. Figures of around 3–4% have been cited for more senior positions in business.<ref name = Snakes> {{Citation | last1 = Baibak | first1 = P | last2 = Hare | first2 = RD | title = [[Snakes in Suits: When Psychopaths Go to Work]] | year = 2007}}.</ref> A 2011 study of Australian white-collar managers found that 5.76 per cent could be classed psychopathic and another 10.42 per cent dysfunctional with psychopathic characteristics.<ref>Saft J [https://www.reuters.com/article/us-markets-saft-idUSKBN19C2Y0 As psychopath CEOs destroy value, nice ones create it] ''[[Reuters]]'' 21 Jun 2017</ref>{{mcn|date=November 2017}}
==The organizational psychopath== The organizational psychopath craves a god-like feeling of [[Abusive power and control|power and control]] over other people. They prefer to work at the very highest levels of their organizations, allowing them to control the greatest number of people. Psychopaths who are political leaders, managers, and CEOs fall into this category.<ref name=Clarke/>
Organizational psychopaths generally appear to be intelligent, sincere, powerful, charming, witty, and entertaining communicators. They quickly assess what people want to hear and then create stories that fit those expectations. They will con people into doing their work for them, take credit for other people's work and even assign their work to junior staff members. They have low patience when dealing with others, display shallow emotions, are unpredictable, undependable and fail to take responsibility if something goes wrong that is their fault.<ref name=Clarke/>
According to a study from the University of Notre Dame published in the ''[[Journal of Business Ethics]],'' psychopaths have a natural advantage in workplaces overrun by abusive supervision, and are more likely to thrive under abusive bosses, being more resistant to stress, including interpersonal abuse, and having less of a need for positive relationships than others.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theladders.com/career-advice/the-surprising-sign-you-may-be-a-psychopath|title=If you're succeeding under a bully boss, you may be a psychopath|work=Ladders {{!}} Business News & Career Advice|access-date=2018-02-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/01/180123171433.htm|title=Flourishing under an abusive boss? You may be a psychopath, study shows|work=ScienceDaily|access-date=2018-02-16|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/psychopaths-thrive-under-abusive-bosses-2018-1|title=An abusive boss is bad news for your work life — unless you're a psychopath|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-02-16}}</ref>
==Careers with highest proportion of psychopaths== According to [[Kevin Dutton|Dutton]], the ten careers that have the highest proportion of psychopaths are:<ref>Dutton K The Wisdom of Psychopaths: What Saints, Spies, and Serial Killers Can Teach Us About Success (2012)</ref> {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| # CEO # Lawyer # Media (TV/radio) # Salesperson # Surgeon # Journalist # Police officer # Clergy # Chef # Civil servant }}
==Behavioural patterns== [[File:Robert_Maxwell_1989.jpg|thumb|right|225px|The face of suspected psychopath [[Robert Maxwell]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bustle.com/p/8-suspected-psychopaths-from-history-whose-stories-are-still-chilling-in-2017-70014|title=8 Suspected Psychopaths From History|last=Peters|first=Lucia|date=13 July 2017|website=[[Bustle (magazine)|Bustle]]|accessdate=13 February 2018}}</ref> The [[media proprietor]] was described by criminal psychologist [[Robert D. Hare]] as a man who "sure had psychopathic tendencies".<ref>{{cite web|title=Are you sitting next to the office psycho?|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-314647/Are-sitting-office-psycho.html|website=Daily Mail|accessdate=17 December 2016|date=19 August 2004}}</ref>]] The workplace psychopath may show a high number of the following behavioural patterns. The individual behaviours themselves are not exclusive to the workplace psychopath; though the higher number of patterns exhibited the more likely he or she will conform to the psychopath's characteristic profile:<ref name=Faggioni>Faggioni M & White M (2009) Organizational Psychopaths – Who Are They and How to Protect Your Organization from Them</ref> * Public [[humiliation]] of others (high propensity of having temper [[tantrum]]s or ridiculing work performance) * Malicious spreading of [[Pathological lying|lies]] (intentionally [[deceitful]]) * Remorseless, or devoid of [[Guilt (emotion)|guilt]] * Frequently lies to push his/her point * Produces exaggerated bodily expressions (yawning, sneezing, etc.) as a means of gaining attention * Rapidly shifts between emotions – used to [[Psychological manipulation|manipulate]] people or cause high anxiety * Intentionally [[Isolation to facilitate abuse|isolates]] persons from organizational resources * Quick to [[blame]] others for mistakes or for incomplete work even though he/she is guilty * Encourages co-workers to torment, alienate, [[harass]] and/or humiliate other peers * Takes credit for other people's accomplishments * Steals and/or [[sabotage]]s other persons' works * Refuses to take responsibility for misjudgements and/or errors * Responds inappropriately to stimuli, such as with a high-pitched and forced laugh * Threatens any perceived enemy with discipline and/or job loss in order to taint employee file * Sets unrealistic and unachievable job expectations to [[Setting up to fail|set employees up for failure]] * Refuses or is reluctant to attend meetings with more than one person * Refuses to provide adequate training and/or instructions to singled out victim * Invades [[Personal boundaries|personal privacy]] of others * Has multiple sexual encounters with other employees * Develops new ideas without real follow through * Very self-centered and extremely [[egotistical]] (often conversation revolves around them – great deal of self-importance) * Often "borrows" money and/or other material objects without any intentions of giving it back * Will do whatever it takes to close the deal (no regard for ethics or legality).
== How a typical workplace psychopath climbs to and maintains power== The authors of the book ''[[Snakes in Suits: When Psychopaths Go to Work]]'' describe a five-phase model of how a typical workplace psychopath climbs to and maintains power:<ref name=Snakes/> # '''Entry''' – psychopaths may use highly developed [[social skills]] and [[Superficial charm|charm]] to obtain employment into an organisation. At this stage it will be difficult to spot anything which is indicative of psychopathic behaviour, and as a new employee one might perceive the psychopath to be helpful and even benevolent. # '''Assessment''' – psychopaths will weigh one up according to one's usefulness, and one could be recognised as either a pawn (who has some informal [[Social influence|influence]] and will be easily manipulated) or a [[Patronage|patron]] (who has formal power and will be used by the psychopath to protect against attacks) # '''[[Psychological manipulation|Manipulation]]''' – psychopath will create a scenario of “[[Cognitive distortion|psychopathic fiction]]” where positive information about themselves and negative [[disinformation]] about others will be created, where one's role as a part of a network of pawns or patrons will be utilised and will be [[Operant conditioning|groomed]] into accepting the psychopath's agenda. # '''Confrontation''' – the psychopath will use techniques of [[character assassination]] to maintain their agenda, and one will be either discarded as a pawn or used as a patron # '''Ascension''' – one's role as a patron in the psychopath's quest for power will be discarded, and the psychopath will take for himself/herself a position of power and prestige from anyone who once supported them.
==Why psychopaths readily get hired== Leading commentators on psychopathy have said that companies inadvertently attract employees who are psychopaths because of the wording of their job advertisements and their desire to engage people who are prepared to do whatever it takes to be successful in business.<ref name=Clarke/><ref name=Snakes/> However, in one case at least, an advert explicitly asked for a sales executive with psychopathic tendencies.<ref>Rodionova Z [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/psychopath-job-advert-radio-relations-sales-executive-listing-a7369471.html Company posts job advert for sales executive with psychopathic qualities] ''[[The Independent]]'' 19 Oct 2016</ref> The advert title read "Psychopathic New Business Media Sales Executive Superstar! £50k - £110k".<ref> McKenzie L [http://home.bt.com/news/odd-news/media-firm-seeks-psychopath-for-sales-role-11364106788842 Media firm seeks ‘psychopath’ for sales role] ''[[BT TV|BT News]]'' 20 Oct 2016</ref>
Corporate psychopaths are readily recruited into organizations because they make a distinctly positive impression at [[Job interview|interviews]].<ref>Cleckley H [[The Mask of Sanity]] (1988)</ref> They appear to be alert, friendly and easy to get along with and talk to.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://pro.psychcentral.com/exhausted-woman/2015/07/do-you-work-with-a-psychopath/|title=Do You Work with a Psychopath? {{!}} The Exhausted Woman|date=2015-07-14|work=The Exhausted Woman|access-date=2018-02-17|language=en-US}}</ref> They look like they are of good ability, emotionally well adjusted and reasonable, and these traits make them attractive to those in charge of hiring staff within organizations. Unlike narcissists, psychopaths are better able to create long-lasting favorable first impressions, though people may still eventually see through their facades.<ref name=fbi>https://leb.fbi.gov/2012/november/the-corporate-psychopath </ref> Psychopaths’ undesirable personality traits may be easily misperceived by even skilled interviewers. For instance, their irresponsibility may be misconstrued by employers as risk-taking or entrepreneurial spirit. Their thrill-seeking tendencies may be conveyed as high energy and enthusiasm for the job or work. Their [[superficial charm]] may be misinterpreted by interviewers as charisma.<ref name=fbi/><ref name = Snakes/> It is worth noting that psychopaths are not only accomplished liars, they are also more likely to lie in interviews.<ref name = "Roulin & Bourdage, 2017"> Roulin, N., & Bourdage, J. S. (2017). Once an Impression Manager, Always an Impression Manager? Antecedents of Honest and Deceptive Impression Management Use and Variability across Multiple Job Interviews. Frontiers in Psychology, 8.</ref> For instance, psychopaths may create fictitious work experiences or resumes.<ref name=fbi/> They may also fabricate credentials such as diplomas, certifications, or awards.<ref name = fbi/> Thus, in addition to seeming competent and likable in interviews, psychopaths are also more likely to outright make-up information during interviews than non-psychopaths.
==Why psychopaths readily get promoted== Corporate psychopaths within organizations may be singled out for rapid promotion because of their polish, [[Superficial charm|charm]], and cool decisiveness.<ref name=Financial>Boddy, C. R The Corporate Psychopaths Theory of the Global Financial Crisis Journal of Business Ethics August 2011, Volume 102, Issue 2, pp 255–259, DOI 10.1007/s10551-011-0810-4 [https://www.springer.com/cda/content/document/cda_downloaddocument/fulltext.pdf?SGWID=0-0-45-1269145-p35739432]</ref> They are also helped by their [[Psychological manipulation|manipulative]] and bullying skills.<ref name=":0" /> They create confusion around them ([[divide and rule]] etc.) using instrumental bullying to promote their own agenda.<ref>[https://online.wsj.com/articles/what-corporate-climbers-can-teach-us-1404862389 What Corporate Climbers Can Teach Us 'Dark' Personality Traits Can Help People Rise Through Ranks] ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' 14 Jul 2014</ref>

R. 2007, ‘A Bully as an Archetypal Destructive Leader', ''[[Journal of Leadership and Organizational Studies]]'' vol. 14, no. 2, pp. 117–129.</ref> * Employees lose their jobs * Legal liabilities * Shareholders lose their investments * Wasted employee time * Suboptimal [[Job performance|employee performance]]<ref>Babiak, P., Neumann, C. S., & Hare, R. D. (2010). Corporate psychopathy: Talking the walk. ''[[Behavioral Sciences & the Law]]'' 28(2), 174–193.</ref><ref name=OBoyle>O'Boyle, E. H., Jr., Forsyth, D. R., Banks, G., & McDaniel, M. (2011). A meta-analysis of the dark triad and work outcomes: A social exchange perspective. ''[[The Journal of Applied Psychology]]'' 97, 557–579.</ref> * Increased [[workload]] * Difficult working conditions * Poor levels of [[job satisfaction]] * Lower perceived levels of [[corporate social responsibility]] * Raised [[Turnover (employment)|staff turnover]] * [[Absenteeism]] * Heightened level of [[workplace conflict]] – arguments, yelling, [[rudeness]], [[Divide and rule|divide and conquer]] * Counterproductive work behavior<ref name=OBoyle/><ref>Bruk-Lee, V., & Spector, P.E. (2006). The social stressors-counterproductive work behaviors link: Are conflicts with supervisors and coworkers the same? ''[[Journal of Occupational Health Psychology]]'' 11, 145–156.</ref>
===Counterproductive work behavior=== {{Main|Counterproductive work behavior}} Boddy suggests that because of [[abusive supervision]] by corporate [[psychopaths]], large amounts of anti-company feeling will be generated among the employees of the organisations that corporate psychopaths work in. This should result in high levels of counterproductive behaviour as employees give vent to their anger with the corporation, which they perceive to be acting through its corporate psychopathic managers in a way that is eminently unfair to them.<ref name=Boddy/>
According to a 2017 UK study, a high ranking corporate psychopath could trigger lower ranked staff to become workplace bullies as a manifestation of counterproductive work behavior.<ref>Beall A [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-4092054/A-toxic-boss-ruin-career-Leaders-psychopathic-narcissistic-tendencies-make-employees-behave-badly-work.html How a toxic boss can ruin your career: Leaders with psychopathic traits could transform you into an office bully] ''Daily Mail'' 6 Jan 2017</ref><ref>Glowatz E [http://www.medicaldaily.com/bad-jobs-if-your-boss-psychopath-you-might-act-one-too-407934 Bad Jobs: If Your Boss Is A Psychopath, You Might Act Like One Too] ''Medical Daily'' 6 Jan 2017</ref>
==Corporate psychopath theory of the global financial crisis== {{Main|Financial crisis of 2007-08}} Boddy makes the case that corporate psychopaths were instrumental in causing the 2007–08 global financial crisis.<ref name=Financial/> He claims that the same corporate psychopaths who probably caused the crisis by greed and avarice are now advising government on how to get out of the crisis.<ref name=Boddy/>
Psychologist [[Oliver James (psychologist)|Oliver James]] has described the [[credit crunch]] as a “mass outbreak of corporate psychopathy which resulted in something that very nearly crashed the whole world economy.”<ref>Psychopath Night [[Channel 4]] (2013).</ref>
For example, during the financial crisis, the behaviour of some key people at the top of the world's largest banks came under scrutiny. At the time of its collapse in 2008 the [[Royal Bank of Scotland]] was the world's fifth largest bank by [[market capitalisation]]. CEO [[Fred Goodwin|Fred "the Shred" Goodwin]] was known for taking excessive risks and showing little concern for his mismanagement, which led to the bank's collapse. Goodwin's demeanour toward colleagues was unpredictable and he is said to have lived a luxury lifestyle while fostering a [[culture of fear]], such that "colleagues suspected he was a psychopath".<ref>{{cite news|last1=McWhirter|first1=Fiona|title=Meat Pies at Midnight...|url=http://www.pressreader.com/uk/the-scottish-mail-on-sunday/20140601/283665412819620|accessdate=25 December 2016|publisher=''[[The Mail on Sunday]]''|date=1 June 2014|quote=Fraser said last week: 'Some ex-colleagues suspect Goodwin may have been a sociopath, a psychopath or have Asperger's syndrome because of his astonishing ability to switch from being witty and convivial with a colleague over a few beers in a bar one evening, to being viciously brutal to the same colleague the next morning}}</ref>
Renowned psychotherapist Professor [[Manfred F. R. Kets de Vries]] singled out Goodwin and former [[Barclays]] CEO [[Bob Diamond (banker)|Bob Diamond]] as exhibiting psychopathic behaviours in his working paper on the SOB, "seductive operational bully - or psychopath lite"<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kets de Vries|first1=Manfred|title=The Psychopathy in the C Suite: Redefining the SOB|publisher=[[INSEAD]]|date=2012|page=14|quote=why was Fred Goodwin, the CEO of Royal Bank of Scotland, able to get away with the things he did?... What's clear is that many of these SOB 'masters of the universe' have been busily destroying the universe for personal gain|url=https://sites.insead.edu/facultyresearch/research/doc.cfm?did=50923|accessdate=25 December 2016}}</ref>
==Screening== From an organizational perspective, organizations can insulate themselves from the organizational psychopath by taking the following steps when recruiting:<ref name=Faggioni/> * conduct [[Behavioural interview|behavioural type interview]] * verify information contained in the [[curriculum vitae]] * conduct reference checks * obtain work samples * carry out criminal reference checks.
The following tests could be used to screen psychopaths: * [[Psychopathy Checklist]]: Screening Version (PCL:SV)<ref>de Silva, P (2014) [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/pnp.344/pdf Tackling psychopathy: a necessary competency in leadership development?] ''Progress in Neurology and Psychiatry'' Vol 18 Iss 5 September/October</ref> * Psychopathy Measure – Management Research Version (PM-MRV)<ref name=Boddy/> * Business-Scan (B-SCAN) test.<ref>Babiak P. & Hare R. D.[http://www.b-scan.com Business-Scan (B-SCAN) test]</ref><ref>Mathieu, C; Hare, R D.; Jones, D N.; Babiak, P; Neumann, C S. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22775409 Factor structure of the B-Scan 360: A measure of corporate psychopathy. ''[[Psychological Assessment]]'' Vol 25(1), Mar 2013, 288–293.]</ref>
There have been anecdotal reports that at least one UK bank was using a psychopathy measure to actively recruit psychopaths.<ref>Corporate Psychopaths, Transcript of Interview with Clive Boddy, Author, part 1 July 28, 2013</ref><ref>Basham B [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/comment/brian-basham-beware-corporate-psychopaths-they-are-still-occupying-positions-of-power-6282502.html Beware corporate psychopaths – they are still occupying positions of power] ''[[The Independent]]'' 29 Dec 2011 </ref>
==Workplace bullying overlap== {{Main|Workplace bullying}} Narcissism, lack of self-regulation, lack of remorse, and lack of conscience have been identified as traits displayed by bullies. These traits are shared with psychopaths, indicating that there is some theoretical cross-over between bullies and psychopaths.<ref name=Harvey/> Bullying is used by corporate psychopaths as a tactic to humiliate subordinates.<ref name=Clarke/> Bullying is also used as a tactic to scare, confuse and disorient those who may be a threat to the activities of the corporate psychopath.<ref name=Clarke/> Using meta data analysis on hundred of UK research papers, Boddy concluded that 36% of bullying incidents was caused by the presence of corporate psychopaths. According to Boddy, there are two types of bullying:<ref name=Boddy/> * Predatory bullying – the bully just enjoys bullying and tormenting [[Vulnerability|vulnerable]] people for the sake of it * Instrumental bullying – the bullying is for a purpose, helping the bully achieve his or her goals.
A corporate psychopath uses instrumental bullying to further his goals of promotion and power as the result of causing confusion and [[divide and rule]].
People with high scores on a psychopathy rating scale are more likely to engage in bullying, crime, and drug use than other people.<ref name=Nathanson>Nathanson, C.; Williams, K. M.; Paulhus, D. L. 2006, "Predictors of a Behavioral Measure of Scholastic Cheating: Personality and Competence but Not Demographics", ''[[Contemporary Educational Psychology]]'' vol. 31, pp. 97–122.</ref> Hare and Babiak noted that about 29 per cent of corporate psychopaths are also bullies.<ref name=Snakes/> Other research has also shown that people with high scores on a psychopathy rating scale were more likely to engage in bullying, again indicating that psychopaths tend to be bullies in the workplace.<ref name=Nathanson/>
A workplace bully or abuser will often have issues with social functioning. These types of people often have psychopathic traits that are difficult to identify in the hiring and promotion process. These individuals often lack [[anger management]] skills and have a distorted sense of reality. Consequently, when confronted with the accusation of abuse, the abuser is not aware that any harm was done.<ref>Ferris, P.A. (2009). The role of the consulting psychologist in the prevention, detection, and correction of bullying and mobbing in the workplace. ''[[Consulting Psychology Journal]]'' 61(3), 169–189.</ref>
